Project development objective Ref. PAD B.2, Technical Annex 3
The objective of the APL program is to help increase the contribution of financial markets to economic growth
through the provision of limited long term finance for rural small and medium enterprises (RSMEs); and
institutional development finance that can play a catalyst role in development of skills, services and respective
market infrastructure. This project (APL1) aims to increase access to financial services in rural areas, specifically
for RSMEs.
Project description [one-sentence summary of each component] Ref. PAD B.3.a, Technical Annex 4
AFSP will finance the first phase of the APL through provision of: (i) a credit line, to be on-lent by the Ministry of
Finance through three commercial banks (Participating Banks - PBs) that meet Project's eligibility criteria, to
eligible RSMEs and agricultural enterprises and SNGs. In addition, it will finance institutional building for these
PBs; (ii) support for enabling environment for financial intermediation through the strengthening of the regulatory
capacity and financial market legislation and infrastructure to support lending to RSMEs and SNGs; and (iii) support
for project management and monitoring and evaluation.
Which safeguard policies are triggered, if any? Ref. PAD D.6, Technical Annex 10
As the project's focus is on a line of credit for rural micro businesses, entrepreneurs, small and medium enterprises,
the majority of sub-loans are not expected to produce any major environmental impact. However, given the rural
nature of the project, agricultural sub-projects which involve application of pesticides and agricultural chemicals
could trigger the safeguard policy on pest management. It is expected that any such sub-projects would be small
scale. However, in order to minimize the risks to human health and environment and to mitigate potential negative
consequences, a pest management plan for such sub-projects has been developed and is included in the
environmental guidelines manual that has been prepared for the project.
Significant, non-standard conditions, if any, for:
Ref. PAD C.7
Loan effectiveness:
·    Subsidiary Loan Agreements are signed with at least two PBs selected in accordance with terms and conditions
     satisfactory to the Bank.
·    Operations Manual, satisfactory to the Bank, finalized and approved by the MoF.
·    A legal opinion is furnished to the Bank, confirming that the Loan Agreement has been duly authorized or
     ratified by the Borrower and is legally binding and valid
·    Legal opinions are furnished to the Bank for at least two signed Subsidiary Loan Agreements (SLA),
     confirming that they have been duly signed by the Borrower and PBs, are legally binding and valid on the
     Borrower and PBs
Covenants applicable to project implementation:
·    On-lending arrangements for passing Loan funds from MoF to PBs
·    Eligibility criteria for sub-borrowers (final beneficiaries) and sub-loans, including subloan limits
·    The Bank to review the first two subloans of each PB above US$50,000 equivalent, any subloan over
     US$1,000,000 and all subloans for SNGs
·    Aggregate amount of subloans to a single final beneficiary (or group of connected beneficiaries) not to exceed
     US$4,000,000
·    The maximum size of subloans will be US$1,500,000 to RSMEs, US$50,000 equivalent (UAH 250,000) to
     micro-enterprises and entrepreneurs and UAH 40,000,000 to SNGs. The maximum size of working capital
     loans will be US$300,000 equivalent.
·    Expenditures for subloans to RSMEs incurred up to 180 days prior to receipt of the subloan application by the
     MoF will be eligible for reimbursement from the Loan
·    The Borrower will maintain, throughout project implementation, the BSMC to verify the continued compliance
     of the PBs with the eligibility criteria under Component A of the Project
·    Up to 15 percent of Component A to be available to PBs for their institutional development investments, only
     after at least 5 percent of the Subsidiary Loan amount has been disbursed for subloans to final beneficiaries.




                                                             ii

                         A. STRATEGIC CONTEXT AND RATIONALE

1. Country and Sector Issues (see Annex 1 for more information)

Ukraine enjoyed a high GDP growth of 50 percent from 1999 through 2004. At 12.1 percent in
2004, GDP growth was the highest in Europe. Growth has been increasingly broad-based, with
industry playing the leading role. Agriculture accounts for about 11 percent of GDP but has
considerable growth potential. The rural economy is largely underdeveloped and suffers from
limited access to finance, obsolete technologies, underdeveloped infrastructure as well as
declining or aging population. During 1999-2004, industrial production grew by 87 percent.
Improved financial discipline, substantial real depreciation of the hryvnia in 1998-99, more
prudent fiscal and monetary policies and improvement of the business climate, have all
contributed to this good performance. Although GDP growth slowed down significantly in 2005
to only 2.4 percent (due mainly to the reduction of prices in the international markets for
Ukraine's main exports such as steel works and chemicals), Ukraine continued its stable
macroeconomic performance and structural reforms. GDP growth for 2006 was previously
projected to be in the range of 3.5 percent to 5.5 percent. However, these estimates have been
lowered by about 2 percent because of the expected impact of the recent gas price increase.

Despite serious efforts of the Government in creating modern legislation and enabling business
environment, significant constraints to the development of the private sector remain. The recent
Country Economic Memorandum (2004) indicates that growth has been concentrated in large
financial-industrial groups that are able to take advantage of growth opportunities in the
domestic and export markets due to their integration with the banking sector. In contrast, rural
and small and medium enterprises (RSMEs) have limited access to credit, restricting the extent
to which they have been able to contribute to GDP growth and benefit from increasing business
opportunities domestically or in foreign markets. Similarly, subnational governments (SNGs),
including utilities, have limited access to long-term funds to meet their capital investment needs.
Only the largest cities have so far been able to attract longer term finance from issuing municipal
bonds while other local governments are constrained by the deficient legal framework and
limited skills in the area of financial planning and project management.

The development of rural finance has been a key priority for consecutive governments of
Ukraine.1 In this context, the authorities have designed a program aimed at increasing overall
access to credit markets with special focus on RMSEs and SNGs.2 This strategy recognizes that,
to be successful, credit markets must be supported in two directions simultaneously: (i) from the
top down, by providing a legal and policy framework that will support efficient credit market
operations; and (ii) from the bottom up, by providing the opportunity to banks and other lenders
to acquire practical experience in making loans and offering new financial services to clients
with limited access to credit.




1In December 2005, the Cabinet of Ministers adopted the "Concept of the Complex Program of Support for Rural
Development".
2Letter, dated May 18, 2006, from the Minister of Finance outlines this program. An unofficial translation is
included as an Attachment to Annex 1.


                                                        1

Throughout the period of 1996-2005, the Bank has played an important role in supporting the
Government's priorities in the above areas. In addition to lending operations and economic and
sector work (ESW), the Bank had an active policy dialogue supporting, inter alia, Ukraine's
efforts to strengthen banking supervision, bank restructuring and financial market development.
In addition to investment loans, lending included a number of policy-based operations which
supported, inter alia, strengthening legislation and supervision of banks and nonbank financial
institutions (NBFIs), liquidation/restructuring of state-owned banks, development of deposit
insurance, improving governance and strengthening property and creditor rights (see Annex 2).
ESW has included policy notes on financial sector reform, a comparative study with other
countries in the region on bank consolidation and a study on the challenges faced in developing
and regulating NBFI services, including insurance, pensions, SNG finance and capital markets.3

This work provides the foundation for the current program of financial sector assistance, which
aims to support the needs of the growing economy as well as address remaining weaknesses and
constraints in the performance of the domestic financial sector. It comprises both policy-based
and investment operations (including the AFSP) (see Box 1). The investment projects are
structured to meet the development objectives of the Government in supporting the reform of
individual segments of the economy (rural SMEs, medium and large exporters, and municipal
water companies).          A series of Development Policy Loans support the overall reform agenda
and provide a platform for policy dialogue. The proposed AFSP Adaptable Program Loan


  Box 1: Planned Lending Operations - 2006
  Development Program Loan 2 (DPL 2) (US$250 million) will focus on a range of policy issues, including
  protection of property rights, improvement of investment climate and creation of sound legal and regulatory
  framework for banks and non-bank financial institutions, introduction of new financial services and development of
  vibrant capital markets by reforming financial legislation. Moreover, the program promotes development of
  sustainable institutions (market regulators, Government agencies and ministries), increased transparency and
  management of public finance, and enhanced governance of private and public sector.
  Export Development Project 2 (EDP 2) (US$150 million) is being prepared as an investment operation, and will
  provide long term finance for medium and large export enterprises (located mainly in industrial regions and urban
  areas) and creation of a functioning export credit and guarantee agency on the basis of the Ukreximbank. This
  project builds upon EDP1 to further promote the entry of new Ukrainian export products and enterprises into
  international markets.
  Access to Financial Services Project (AFSP) is a two-phase Adaptable Program Loan (APL). APL1 (US$150
  million) aims to increase access to financial services in rural areas, especially for RSMEs. It will (i) provide long
  term finance through eligible commercial banks for RSMEs and on a pilot basis for SNGs; (ii) support institutional
  development of the selected commercial banks; and (iii) provide support to improve the enabling environment for
  financial intermediation through strengthening of the regulatory capacity and financial market legislation, and
  enhancing financial sector infrastructure.
  Urban Infrastructure Project: (US$140 million) is designed to assist the Ministry of Construction and water
  authorities of several participating cities: (i) to prepare annual business plans and improve their financial
  management capacity; and (ii) access targeted longer term financing to meet the investment needs of the cities in
  mitigating serious health and environmental risks posed by the water, wastewater and solid waste sectors, as well as
  replace old equipment with more efficient and energy saving technology.



 3 Financial Sector Policy Notes (1995, 2001), provided overview of the financial sector development and reform
   agenda for the banks and NBFIs; Comparative Study on Bank Consolidation (2003); and the NBFI Study (2005).




                                                              2

(APL) supports the implementation of the Government's program to improve access to finance
in rural areas, as well as of SNGs.

Overall Financial Sector Context

The financial sector of Ukraine has developed significantly over the last several years and total
assets reached nearly 55 percent of GDP by the end of 2005. However, the quality, variety and
accessibility of the financial services, especially in rural areas, is still inadequate, and the
financial sector is dominated by banks (which account for over 85 percent of the sector's total
assets). Non-bank financial institutions (NBFI) are underdeveloped and constitute less than 10
percent of GDP. The insurance industry, the largest segment of NBFI market, has been growing
rapidly. Gross premium income was about 4 percent of GDP in 2005. Pension funds, credit
unions, leasing and factoring companies are negligible, accounting for less than 1 percent of
GDP. The securities market remains shallow, illiquid and non-transparent.

Banking Sector

There were 162 operating banks at the beginning of 2006, including 2 State-owned and 9 fully
foreign-owned banks. Eighty-five banks are based in Kyiv; others are located in the main
industrial and business regions. As of end 2005, the ten largest banks (including 2 state-owned
and 2 foreign banks that belonged to the Raiffeisen Group ­ Aval Bank and Raiffeisenbank
Ukraina) accounted for about 54 percent of net assets of the banking sector and about 43 percent
of total capital. State-owned banks constitute only about 8 percent of assets and 5 percent of the
capital of the banking sector. The balance of banking system is fragmented, with numerous
small "pocket-banks" which often belong to industrial groups and are used for the cash flow
management of their parent enterprises. The banks suffered a run on deposits during the time
leading to the "Orange Revolution". A systemic crisis was avoided with the injection of UAH
5.8 billion (or 5 percent of the deposit base) by the National Bank of Ukraine (NBU).

As of end December 2005, total assets of the banking system increased to UAH 223 billion (US$
44.2 billion). Household and business deposits totaled UAH 133 billion (US$26.3 billion) or 32
percent of GDP. The capital adequacy ratio for the system as a whole was reportedly 14.9
percent by end-2005. However, given concerns relating to the opaqueness of ownership, and
hence related lending and its potential impact on the quality of assets, this figure may be over-
stated.

To date, the banking sector lacks access to long-term funding. More than 90 percent of deposits
have maturities of less than one year and more than 50 percent of the system's aggregate loan
portfolio has less than one year maturity. Real interest rates on bank loans remain high, but are
expected to decrease with the entry of reputable foreign banks to the system and increased
competition. This should also lead to an overall improvement in the quality of banking services.

In 2005 and early 2006, there was a significant entry of reputable foreign banks into Ukraine
through the purchase of a number of large and medium size banks. As a result, by April 2006,



                                                  3

majority foreign-owned banks controlled more than 35 percent of banking sector assets
(compared to only 11 percent in 2004). This trend is expected to continue.

The NBU is the regulator of the banking sector. A relatively modern legal/regulatory framework
is in place, albeit with certain important gaps such as disclosure of information on bank
ownership, related-parties transactions, as well as weak bank risk management. In addition
supervisory enforcement needs to be strengthened. The NBU is aware of the need to further
strengthen banking legislation and supervision and is using external technical assistance,
including from the World Bank, IMF and US Treasury, to upgrade its capacity, introduce risk-
based supervision and gradually move towards Basle II.

Non-bank financial institutions (NBFIs)

The NBFIs are regulated by the State Commission for Regulation of Financial Services Markets
(SCRFSM) or the State Securities Commission. The SCRFSM, established in December 2002,
is responsible for regulation and supervision of insurers, credit unions, non-Government pension
funds, leasing and factoring companies, pawnshops, and other financial institutions (such as
construction trust funds, etc). In response to the increasing importance of the NBFI service
providers and the still largely inadequate legal and regulatory framework for NBFIs, efforts are
needed to ensure that the SCRFSM, has adequate legal powers, funding and skills to carry out its
mandate.

Currently over 700 Credit Unions (CUs), providing services to more than 1 million individual
members, are registered with the SCRFSM. As of September 2005, total assets of CUs were
UAH 1.59 billion (US$310 million). More than 140 CUs (with 130,000 members) are members
of the National Association of Credit Unions (NACSU).4 Almost 60 percent of CUs are very
small, with only 100 to 500 members, and operate primarily in local communities.

NACSU monitors and self-regulates its members. It is dominated by several larger urban credit
unions. This has led to the formation, largely by the rural CUs, of 16 regional credit union
associations. CUs can play an important role in financial intermediation since they generally
have simple lending processes, based on personal knowledge of the borrower and past credit
behavior. However, CUs remain underdeveloped and are engaged primarily in urban consumer
lending due in part to a weak legal and regulatory framework, especially the governance
structure of NACSU.

Despite the high demand for capital investments and the need for replacement of obsolete fixed
assets, the leasing industry is seriously underdeveloped. Total lease revenues, in 2004, were
estimated at about 1 percent or less of GDP. Only 20 (including 3 state-owned companies) of the
40 registered leasing companies are operating.                Many leasing companies are in-house,
functioning more as captive finance companies dependent on the cash flow of the enterprise (or
enterprises) they serve. Commercial banks can also provide leasing products but these have been
limited, mainly due to the yet underdeveloped skills and lack of long-term funds.           Some
reputable foreign financial groups have recently shown interest in establishing leasing companies


4About 70 CUs lend in rural areas with loans ranging from UAH 60-30,000.


                                                        4

in Ukraine. In addition, a new leasing association has been established to promote the interests
of the leasing industry.

Mortgage finance activity is small but growing rapidly. During 2005 mortgage financing more
than tripled, reaching UAH 10.6 billion (2.5 percent of GDP) with the residential housing
finance loans amounting to about 1.6 percent of GDP. Mortgage loans make up 7.4 percent of
the total lending portfolio of banks. Thirteen banks control 78 percent of the residential housing
mortgage financing market.

To support liquidity of the mortgage market and provide refinancing to banks, in November
2004, the Government established the State Mortgage Institution (SMI) with a statutory capital
of UAH 20 million. The original strategy was to establish SMI as a liquidity facility, with
potential to expand its services once it has developed adequate management, skills and
procedures. Although the Government has recently been discussing other areas for SMI's
potential intervention, it is expected that the recently appointed management of SMI will
formulate a clearly defined strategy and a business plan for SMI's future operation in a non-
distortionary manner and at the lowest fiscal costs. Substantial support will be needed to ensure
that government housing policies do not undermine market practices and that the SMI operates in
accordance with prudent financial practices. This would require that the Government fine-tune
the legislation and reconsider its proposed strategy for subsidized mortgage finance to ensure
that it does not distort the market. The policy dialogue and conditionality relating to this issue
are beyond the scope of the current operation but are being pursed in the context of the
Development Policy Loan (DPL) series. Several donors, including USAID and TACIS, as well
as the Bank, have been providing assistance to the Government in the preparation of legislation
and the development of a secondary mortgage market. In this regard, USAID is implementing a
substantial technical assistance program on access to credit and on capital markets.                         This
program includes support for the SCRFSM and the SMI.

Small and Medium Enterprises

SMEs contribute significantly to employment and GDP, and provide the only employment and
income source to many poor households.5 Attention to their development is therefore essential
for economic growth and poverty reduction. At the lower end of the SME sector is a mixture of
the self-employed and "micro" enterprises, with less than 10 employees. A significant proportion
of these enterprises are found in the informal sector.

The 2002 reform of state collective farms resulted in reorganization and/or liquidation of almost
15,000 large public agricultural production enterprises and led to the creation of about 45,000
new farmer enterprises as well as the growth of rural SMEs. Many of these new enterprises
require significant funding to purchase production equipment and replace obsolete machinery.
Overall limited access to credit of the newly established enterprises has significantly hampered
the performance and growth of the RSMEs. As agriculture and the rural economy make up a
significant proportion of GDP, addressing the impediments to the growth of the sector is high on
the Government's reform agenda.


5The share of the SME sector in GDP is currently only 8 percent but it employs 21 percent of the labor force.


                                                        5

SNGs

With the exception of short-term borrowing for budget deficit financing, there is no significant
borrowing by SNGs outside Kyiv. This situation hinders the ability of the central government to
decentralize important parts of local public service delivery. Furthermore, lack of access to
financial services limits the provision and coverage of local services that SNGs provide, since
they are unable to finance the capital costs required to upgrade or expand infrastructure
networks. Lack of a SNG credit market, in short, is preventing the development of a public
finance system that assigns significant decision-making power and financing responsibility to
SNGs. The existing legal framework for SNG borrowing does not comprehensively and
consistently address the issues related to SNG debt. Relevant rules are largely indirect, scattered
among various laws, decrees and regulations or established on an informal basis. In several
instances, they are inconsistent, incomplete or ambiguous, further exacerbating the legal
uncertainty for SNG lending.

Access to Credit Issues

Constraints on both the supply and demand sides limit access to credit by all potential borrowers,
especially RSMEs and SNGs. Constraints include the following: (i) the financial infrastructure is
insufficiently developed to aid financial intermediaries in their assessment and mitigation of risk,
for example, inadequate information on the repayment history of borrowers (through well-
functioning credit bureaus, credit rating agencies and secured transactions registry for movable
property); (ii) the financial position of potential borrowers, especially in rural areas, is difficult to
ascertain due to unreliable financial reporting (financial statements are prepared primarily for tax
purposes and are not consistent with International Financial Reporting Standards--IFRS); (iii) an
inadequate legal and judicial framework provides weak protection of creditors' rights resulting in
excessive requirements for collateral (that makes it difficult for SMEs to borrow) and costly
dispute resolution process that increases the cost of lending; and (iv) high cost and short maturity
of loans discourage potential borrowers from applying for loans. In addition, the banks to date
have focused largely on relationship lending, making decisions on the basis of direct contacts
and knowledge of the borrower, which in many cases may have a controlling interest in the
lending bank. They have not invested in the development of systems, products and services to
enable them to engage with a broader range of clients.

In spite of progress in developing a sustainable local government system, challenges remain.
Although the basic framework is in place (e.g. Budget Code), legislation for SNG borrowing and
SNG debt remains dispersed and, in some instances, internally inconsistent. Almost all SNGS
have enormous investment needs to upgrade infrastructure and services, but under current
legislation oblasts, rayons, towns, villages and settlements cannot borrow, except to cover
current budget cash gaps. Nonetheless, some large banks are beginning to provide loans to the
utility companies against physical collateral, with the guarantee of the owner municipalities.

The proposed APL aims at addressing these constraints to accelerate access to credit by
providing strong foundations for the development of market-based financial services, through the
provision of TA and long-term financial resources. In regard to SNGs, the proposed APL1 aims



                                                   6

to improve the environment for bank lending by assisting the authorities develop the legal and
policy framework that is a prerequisite for increased market-based intermediation.6 A limited
amount of funding for on-lending to SNGs (on a pilot basis) could be considered for inclusion in
the project during the course of implementation, once the appropriate legal and policy framework
(satisfactory to the Bank) is in place. APL2 would provide additional long-term funding for
SNG investments as well as RSMEs. It is anticipated that CUs and leasing companies would
also qualify as participating financial intermediaries.

The Government's strategy for improving access to credit

The authorities have designed a program (see the letter of the Minister of Finance dated May 18,
2006) aimed at increasing overall access to credit markets with special focus on RMSEs and
SNGs, as their funding needs are not adequately met by the financial sector.

The Government strategy is predicated on the idea that credit markets must be built in two
directions. First from the top down, in terms of a legal and policy framework that will support
efficient credit market operations. And second from the bottom up, in terms of practical
experience for banks and other lenders in making loans to the clients with limited access today.
Both tracks, namely building a supportive legal and policy framework and accumulating
practical experience in RSMEs and SNGs lending are envisioned to move forward
simultaneously under the program.

The following will be the public policy interventions supported by the program: (a) assisting the
banking sector to develop the capacity to provide more diverse financial services, in order to
reduce the transaction costs' gap between lenders and potential borrowers and improve outreach
to new clients; (b) enhancing the protection of creditors rights to lessen the risk of lending to
potential borrowers; (c) building up the credit market infrastructure and new financial products
to make credit transactions more attractive to both borrowers and lenders; (d) providing technical
assistance to prepare the foundation for commercial borrowing by SNGs; and (e) making
available a comparatively modest amount of well-targeted and properly priced long-term credit
funds to trigger implementation of the program and promote rapid market take up of the
opportunities thereby created. 7

To bring about this new vision, the Government strategy includes:

·   Providing banks access to long-term resources for on-lending to RSMEs and SNGs.
·   Assisting financial intermediaries expand their presence in rural areas by accessing new
    clients and acquire the lending technologies suitable for lending to RSMEs and SNGs.



6 Legal reforms being supported under the project relate to credit relations between private lenders and SNGs. The
Bank, as part of its analytical and advisory activities (e.g., CEM) and adjustment lending operations has been
supporting Ukraine address issues related to fiscal policy and inter-government finance.
7 A Japanese PHRD Grant (TF025598) and a Project Preparation Facility (PPF P4020-UA) have supported the
design and initial implementation of the government program. In addition, several consultants' trust funds (CTFs)
have been used to finance smaller individual experts assignments (in the area of mortgage, insurance, secured
transactions reform).


                                                           7

·   Upgrading the lending infrastructure (policy, legal, regulatory and institutional) to stimulate
    the development of the financial services market.8

2. Rationale for Bank involvement

The Bank is well positioned to add value in supporting the authorities in the development and
implementation of the program, including providing technical assistance and advice on a broad
range of policy issues relating to the financial sector in general, as well as access to finance for
RSMEs and SNGs. Through its involvement in the proposed Project, the Bank can contribute to
the achievement of the program's objectives.

As part of project preparation, the Bank has helped the Government develop its vision to increase
access to credit markets by RSMEs and SGNs, identify benchmarks and milestones to reach the
intended objectives, and obtain the required technical assistance either directly or through grants
from donors, such as the Japanese Government and other bilateral donors. The Government
looks to the Bank for leadership in this area, including in coordinating donor support.

3. Higher level objectives to which the project contributes

The project will help create the conditions for the development of an internationally competitive
private sector. It will support the Government's priority program to develop regional economies,
financial market infrastructure and rural and municipal credit markets.                         In pursuing this
objective, the project will assist in: (a) accelerating economic transformation by increasing the
flow of credit resources to sectors that, by and large, have been excluded from financial markets,
(b) increasing the contribution of RSMEs to the economy by improving their access to financial
services, and (c) improving the quality of local public services through an improved environment
for and investments in local infrastructure.

These objectives are fully consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for 2004-2007
discussed by the Board on September 29, 2003, and the CAS Progress Report (June 13, 2005)
discussed by the Board on July 5, 2005. The CAS supports the aspirations of Ukraine to join the
EU by continuing to facilitate institutional developments that can lead to a business-friendly
environment and a more inclusive and responsive government. The CAS is built around seven
broad objectives, including three relating to: (a) sustainable economic growth, with particular
emphasis on the environment for private sector development; (b) poverty reduction and
strengthening of the middle class; and (c) reducing regional imbalances. The proposed Access to
Financial Services APL will contribute to each of these objectives by jump-starting RSMEs and
SNGs access to credit markets. This in turn will lead, in the medium term, to employment
generation and hence poverty reduction.




8Some measures have already been undertaken toward improving the lending environment (particularly on the
legislative side) for RSMEs and to put in place a decentralized structure to enable borrowing by SNGs.



                                                          8

                                        B. PROJECT DESCRIPTION

1.       Lending Instrument

The Loan is structured as a vertical APL supporting a longer term Government reform program
that will be implemented in two phases during 2006-2013. Each phase of the program would be
implemented over a period of about four years. The proposed size of the APL lending facility is
US$300 million. The lending instrument proposed for the AFSP (APL1) will be a Bank's
Variable Spread Loan (VSL) in US dollar with a 20-year maturity, including a 5-year grace
period.

During the first phase (2006-2010), the Project (APL1) will provide medium to longer-term
finance to Ukrainian enterprises by intermediation of a credit line through eligible commercial
banks. In addition, it will provide institutional building finance for banks as well as technical
assistance for development of enabling environment for financial intermediation. The project is
justified since medium to longer term finance is limited in Ukraine and there is a strong demand
for longer term investment resources in rural areas to replace obsolete equipment and develop
modern financial sector infrastructure.

The APL instrument was chosen to allow for flexibility in program execution required to
gradually strengthen the capacity of eligible participating financial intermediaries to lend to
RSMEs and SNGs; and to strengthen the legal, regulatory, and institutional framework for
increasing access to credit.

2.       Program Objective and Phases

The Program Objective is to help increase the contribution of financial markets to economic
growth through provision of limited longer term finance for RSMEs and institutional
development finance that can play a catalyst role in development of skills, services and
respective market infrastructure of rural finance market in Ukraine. APL1 (with a total cost of
about US$185 million, of which US$150 million9 will be Bank financed) will outline the global
program, setting out the frameworks required for project continuity in the long-run. It will
support inter alia: (a) the provision of credit to RSMEs10 and agricultural enterprises; (b) the
provision of credit to strengthen the lending skills of financial intermediaries; and (c) the
provision of technical assistance to support the strengthening of the credit market infrastructure,
legal and regulatory framework to expand access to finance for RSMEs and SNGs. It is
envisaged that pilot lending to SNGs could be provided under APL1, once an acceptable
legislative framework is in place.11




9Including the front end fee of US$375,000.
10Including micro-enterprises and entrepreneurs.
11The economic reform agenda of the Government of Ukraine calls for significant investments in urban and rural
infrastructure, housing and utilities. However, these investments are not feasible without passage of subnational
government debt legislation, reform of municipal finance system, and creation of a framework conducive for
development of vibrant mortgage and housing finance markets.



                                                           9

APL2 would build upon the institutional development of APL1. Consequently, it is expected
that APL2 would maintain a credit line component, with the participation of a broader scope of
financial intermediaries (such as Credit Unions and leasing companies) and more extensive
lending to SNGs. It would focus mainly on second generation financial sector issues, including
risk-based financial sector supervision (e.g., Basle II) and credit scoring systems to further
facilitate RSMEs access to credit, development of sophisticated risk management instruments for
the productive sector such as weather-based agricultural insurance and commodity exchanges.

The triggers for moving from the first phase to the second phase will be:

    ·   at least 60 percent of the line of credit disbursed;
    ·   less than 5 percent of the average outstanding sub-loans are classified as non-performing
        (doubtful and loss) while fully provisioned;
    ·    A satisfactory legal and regulatory framework is in place for leasing, factoring and credit
        unions (if these institutions to be included in APL2);
    ·   A satisfactory framework for SNG borrowing is in place, including the enforcement of a
        law on SNG borrowing that is acceptable to the Bank;
    ·   The Government has refrained from making credit lines (and or guarantees) available on
        non-market terms and conditions that could substantially undermine the objectives of the
        APL.

3.      Project Development Objective and Key Indicators

The Project Development Objective (PDO) is to increase access to financial services in rural
areas, specifically for RSMEs. The key indicator will be an increase in the number of RSME
clients on the books of the PBs, compared to the situation as of late-2006. This would mean a
significant increase in the absolute amount of credit to RSMEs, as the banking sector is expected
to continue to experience fast real growth. Other key indicators will be an increase in the volume
of longer term finance extended by the PBs to RSMEs, legislation enacted relating to new
financial services and improved infrastructure and legislation to support financial services.

4.      Project Components

APL1 consists of three components (excluding the front end fee - Annex 4):

Component A: Access to Finance (about US$140 million or up to 93.6 percent of loan). This
component includes two sub-components:

        (1) A line of credit (about US$125 million) to provide long-term subloans (for
        investments, working capital or financial leases) through three Participating Banks (PBs)
        to: (i) eligible RSMEs and (ii) eligible agricultural enterprises. The three PBs (Pryvat
        Bank, Nadra Bank and Kreditprombank) were selected based on agreed criteria,
        including inter alia, the requirement that they operate under sound commercial principles,
        meet minimum financial performance and sound corporate governance standards and are
        in full compliance with NBU prudential regulations. Eligible RSMEs and agricultural
        enterprises will private sector legal entities, as well as microenterprises and



                                                  10

        entrepreneurs. The maximum size of sub-loans for RSMEs and agricultural enterprises
        would be US$1.5 million equivalent, unless the Bank, on an exceptional basis, agrees
        otherwise. The maximum size for working capital subloans will be US$300,000. Micro-
        subloans will be below UAH 250,000. (See Annex 6 for more details on eligibility
        requirements.) Detailed criteria for PBs, sub-borrowers and subloans are provided in
        Annex 6 and its attachments. Information on the PBs is provided in the Attachment to
        Annex 4. Lending to SNGs, on a pilot basis, could be considered for inclusion in the line
        of credit, if satisfactory legislation on the SNG borrowing and guarantees is put in place
        during project implementation and there is verifiable demand from SNG eligible
        borrowers. Otherwise, SNG financing will be considered under Phase 2 of the Program.
        The maximum size of subloans for SNGs will be UAH 40,000,000.

        (2) Institutional Development for PBs (about US$15 million). Funding from Component
        A (up to a maximum of 15 percent of this component) will be made available to the PBs
        to invest in their institutional development and information technology (IT) upgrading
        needs that support the achievement of the project objectives. PBs will have the option of
        shifting all or part of this allocation to the line of credit, should they decide during the
        course of implementation that they prefer to use their own funds for their institutional/IT
        development needs.

Component B: Enabling Environment for Financial Intermediation (US$ 8.0 million or
about 5.4 percent of loan). This component will finance institutional development (consulting
services and IT/MIS) as well as training of the Ministry of Finance and selected beneficiary
institutions (including the SCRFSM, Credit Bureau, SMI) to address the legislative and
institutional constraints which are impeding the expansion of financial intermediation, through
the strengthening of the regulatory capacity and financial market legislation; enhancing financial
sector and credit market infrastructure and improving the framework for borrowing by SNGs.

Component C: Project Management and Monitoring (about US$1.6 million or 1.0 percent of
loan). The APL1 will finance the staffing for the PMU as well as incremental expenditures
incurred by the MoF for project implementation, monitoring and evaluation. It is anticipated that,
by the time of APL2, the PMU will be mainstreamed into the structure of the MoF. Special
provisions will be incorporated in the project, including for carrying out small surveys and focus
groups to support project monitoring and evaluation (see Annex 6 for more information). It will
also cover the cost of the annual audit of the Project accounts.

5.      Lessons learned and reflected in the project design

Experience with the financing of credit lines has been mixed but recent evaluations across
several countries, including, inter alia, Turkey, India and Poland, indicate that problems include:

(i)      inadequate demand from project beneficiaries, lack of bankable subprojects.            The
         tendency to over-estimate the amount and pace of utilization of credit line resources has
         resulted in a large number of financial intermediary loans with slow disbursements and
         partially cancelled Bank loans across all Regions. Under this project, to help avoid an
         overstatement of demand, the commercial banks have provided an estimate of the



                                                   11

          funding they seek from the Loan and will have to pay a penalty (of up to one percent of
          this amount) if they fail to conclude the subsequent subsidiary loan agreements within an
          agreed timeframe.         Furthermore, funding will be provided to cover only a small
          proportion of the overall demand. As part of the agreed programs with the PBs,
          incentives and penalties will help ensure utilization of the funds.

 (ii)     weak accountability and capacity, lack of clearly defined and transparent indicators for
          monitoring performance of the financial intermediaries, as well as poor monitoring of
          overall project impact. Under the project, three PBs have been selected based on clear
          eligibility criteria to ensure that they are financially sound, are well-managed and have
          robust policies, procedures and practices. To strengthen accountability, project activities
          will be frequently and closely monitored both at the level of the PBs and the PMU, based
          on pre-defined criteria and indicators. In addition, the Borrower (MoF) intends to build
          in remedies should PBs fail to fulfill their obligations.

(iii)    an appropriate policy, institutional, and legal framework is a precondition for the healthy
         growth of financial intermediation. Such an environment reduces uncertainty, allows the
         banks to more accurately measure and price the risk of lending, as well as to better
         mitigate against possible default.              The shortcomings of the legal and institutional
         framework in Ukraine contribute to the high cost and risks of lending and possible
         adverse selection, leading to low levels of intermediation particularly to the APL target
         groups. The project aims at reducing these costs and risks through Component B,
         including during project preparation with support from the PHRD Grant and the PPF for
         this operation.

6.       Alternatives considered and reasons for rejection

This project has had a long gestation, during which time many alternatives have been considered.
The result is an operation that is more attuned to the current Government's objectives and
implementation requirements.

The main alternative considered was to have two separate Bank loans: a project aimed at
increasing access to finance by RSMEs and a project for SNGs. For country programming
reasons, since a number of issues limiting access to financial services, especially those relating to
the enabling environment and infrastructure, were common to both clients, it was subsequently
decided to merge the two operations.12

The APL approach facilitates the design of a program which recognizes the different stage of
preparation of the various components, especially the need to adopt legislation relating to SNG
borrowing.13 A trigger for APL2 is the requirement that a satisfactory framework for SNG
borrowing, including the enforcement of a law on SNG borrowing, be in place. However,



12This decision was made following a Quality Enhancement Review (QER) meeting held in February 2005.
13A small pilot program of US$7 million funded by the Ministry of Finance in 2001 has not been disbursed yet due
to the lack of interest of commercial banks, owing to the ambiguous legislation on the rights of SNG borrowers in
using their assets and cash proceeds as collateral for loans.


                                                           12

flexibility is retained in APL1 to allow some lending to SNGs on a pilot basis, if these conditions
are met during implementation of APL1.

During the early stages of the Program's conceptual design, consideration was given to including
SNG financing as part of the budgetary process. This idea was rejected because of the risk of
making lending decisions based on political rather than commercial factors. Consideration was
also given to providing separate loans for technical assistance and a line of credit. This idea was
rejected because separate loans would not be attractive for the Borrower.

Other alternatives considered included: (i) having the NBU as the borrower and implementing
agency since the NBU has a proven record in managing lines of credit and, as the regulator, has a
close relationship with the banks. This option was rejected by the Ministry of Finance as it
wished to play a more central role in the preparation and implementation of the operation, and
use the opportunity to build capacity in the Ministry; and, (ii) on-lending to eligible leasing
companies and CUs. This was dropped in the absence of a satisfactory legal and regulatory
environment and in view of the weak institutional performance of leasing companies and CUs.
If these issues are addressed, these institutions are expected to be able to participate in APL2.

                                          C. IMPLEMENTATION

1. Institutional and implementation arrangements:

The Ministry of Finance (MoF) will be the representative of the Borrower and have overall
responsibility for project implementation. The Project will be implemented through a Project
Management Unit (PMU) in the MoF. Funds for Component A will be onlent by the MoF to
three preselected PBs under Subsidiary Loan Agreements (SLAs), satisfactory to the Bank.
Conclusion of at least two SLAs (satisfactory to the Bank) between the MoF and the PBs is a
condition of effectiveness of the proposed Project. PBs will be responsible for implementation
of Component A. MoF will administer and manage the funds and activities for Components B
and C. The MoF in its role as the Borrower and implementing agency will be responsible for
ensuring that the project is efficiently implemented.

The PMU, headed by a Director, has been established and adequately staffed.14 Resources are
provided in the Project for additional support as needed. The Minister or Finance is the Project
Coordinator and the primary project counterpart and he has authorized the Deputy Minister to
provide regular oversight and guidance to the PMU. The PMU will be responsible for the
overall administration of the project, coordination with project beneficiaries and reporting to the
Bank. More details of the institutional arrangements for project management are described in
Annex 6.

For the purposes of Component A, a Bank Selection and Monitoring Commission (BSMC) has
been established (through an order of the Cabinet of Ministers) with the participation of the MoF
and NBU. Prior to appraisal, based on the agreed selection criteria, the banks were pre-selected
by the BSMC, with the NBU playing a key role. The Bank has provided its no objection to three


14 Initial support for the PMU, including its staff, has been funded from the Project's PPF.


                                                           13

pre-selected banks. The BSMC will be maintained during project implementation to help verify
the PBs' continued compliance with the eligibility criteria.

PBs will have the key role in implementing Component A of the project. Subloans to final
beneficiaries will be made on commercial terms, in accordance with the policies and procedures
of the PBs. PBs will bear the commercial risk and will be responsible for subproject appraisal
and all lending decisions. Subloans to RSMEs could be made in US$ (for exporters) or UAH.
Microlending will be in UAH.

The first two sub-loans of each PB above US$50,000 equivalent, all sub-loans to RSMEs of
US$1.0 million equivalent and above, and all subloans to SNGs will be subject to prior review
by the Bank. The PMU will review all such applications and provide recommendations on
whether they meet the eligibility criteria, prior to submission to the Bank. All other sub-loans
will be subject to post-review by the Bank.

The PBs may use the funds under Subcomponent A2 for their own institutional development and
IT needs. These activities will be consistent with the PB's overall business strategy and planning
and will be agreed with the Bank during the course of project implementation. Given the lead
time needed for moving ahead with these activities, it is expected that each PB will have
disbursed at least 5 percent of its Subsidiary Loan for subloans before these activities are
initiated.

Currently the legislation relating to borrowing by SNGs does not provide adequate, unambiguous
authority to SNGs to borrow for more than one year for investment needs or to use SNG assets
and payment proceeds as collateral. Nor does it provide adequate protection to the creditors in
case of SNG's default since courts will not issue decisions against local authorities. As the
existence of such legislation, satisfactory to the Bank, is fundamental for prudent commercial
bank lending to SNGs, lending to SNGs on a pilot basis, may be considered for inclusion in the
project, only once satisfactory legislation is in place. Legislation to this effect has been drafted
but has not yet been submitted to Parliament.15

2.      Monitoring and Evaluation of Outcomes/Results

Progress in achieving the Program's objectives will be measured through a comprehensive
monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system to be established by the PMU, including the use of
surveys of subloan beneficiaries. The M&E system will provide information on specific targets
for project performance indicators (see Annex 3), based on data collected from the PBs and the
beneficiaries of any project-related technical assistance. A mid-term review, to be held about
two years after loan effectiveness (by about June 2008), will include a detailed assessment of
progress and achievements to date and will serve as the basis to determine readiness to proceed
with the APL2.

The PBs and beneficiaries will maintain all records necessary to measure the performance and
viability of their project-related activities. Records will be available for review by the PMU and

15Such sub-projects would also be likely to support urgently required rehabilitation or equipment for vital services
while further attention is given to the application of appropriate cost recovery mechanisms and their management.


                                                           14

Bank staff, as necessary. The PMU will prepare, and submit to the Bank for its review,
consolidated quarterly reports,16 based on information provided by the PBs and beneficiaries.
The Bank will conduct implementation reviews, as part of its normal supervision, on a semi-
annual basis, supplemented by more frequent reviews during the initial implementation period.
An Implementation Completion Report (ICR) will be prepared within six months of the project's
Closing Date.

3.       Sustainability

Project sustainability is ensured by the Government's commitment to increase access to finance
to RSMEs and to foster agricultural and rural development, as well as to put in place the
necessary legal and regulatory environment to facilitate borrowing by SNGs. The project has
been under preparation for some time and, throughout this period, different governments (and
political parties) have continuously supported the above objective. The phased approach of the
APL permits attention to be paid initially to putting in place the necessary legal framework and
developing the appropriate capacity to permit borrowing on a commercial basis by SNGs.
Lending to RSMEs would increase and lending to SNGs could be scaled up during the second
phase, once the appropriate conditions are in place. Ukrainian banks are increasingly focusing
on lending to the rural SME segment and are looking at developing new financial sector
products. This trend is likely to continue. Lending to SNGs offers tremendous potential for
commercial banks and the PBs are anxious to tap into this once the appropriate environment,
including legislation to protect creditors' rights, is in place. Support provided under Component
B of the project aims to help further the reform of the legal and regulatory framework and build
institutional capacities of regulatory agencies, market infrastructure institutions and market
participants. The results of these efforts would have a sustainable long-term impact on the
financial markets and their interaction with the real sector. These benefits would continue
beyond the end of the APL.

4.       Critical Risks and Possible Controversial Aspects

Critical risks that may impede successful project implementation are identified below. In
addition, it should be noted that there is a risk that political developments relating to the recent
elections and the lack of project management experience in the MoF could increase the
uncertainty of the timely delivery of this project. The timing could be exacerbated by lengthy
authorization procedures in Ukraine, which have in the past caused delays in signing and
effectiveness of other projects.

5.        Loan/Credit Conditions and Covenants

Loan effectiveness:
·   A legal opinion is furnished to the Bank, confirming that the Loan Agreement has been duly
    authorized or ratified by the Borrowers and is legally binding and valid on the Borrower
·   Subsidiary Loan Agreements are executed with at least two PBs, in accordance with terms
    and conditions satisfactory to the Bank
·   Legal opinions are furnished to the Bank on least two signed Subsidiary Loan Agreements,
    confirming they have been duly signed by the Borrower and PBs and are legally binding and
    valid on the Borrower and PBs
·   The Operations Manual, satisfactory to the Bank, is finalized and approved by the MoF.

Other Covenants:
·   On-lending arrangements for passing Loan funds from MoF to PBs
·   Eligibility criteria for sub-borrowers (final beneficiaries) and sub-loans, including subloan
    limits
·   The Bank to review the first two subloans of each PB above US$50,000 equivalent, any
    subloan over US$1,000,000 and all subloans for SNGs
·   Aggregate amount of subloans to a single final beneficiary (or group of connected
    beneficiaries) not to exceed US$4,000,000



                                                        16

·   The maximum size of subloans will be US$1,500,000 to RSMEs, US$50,000 equivalent
    (UAH 250,000) to micro-enterprises and entrepreneurs and UAH 40,000,000 to SNGs. The
    maximum size of working capital loans will be US$300,000 equivalent.
·   Expenditures for subloans to RSMEs incurred up to 180 days prior to receipt of the subloan
    application by the MoF will be eligible for reimbursement from the Loan
·   The Borrower will maintain, throughout project implementation, the BSMC to verify the
    continued compliance of the PBs with the eligibility criteria under Component A of the
    Project
·   Up to 15 percent of Component A to be available to PBs for their institutional development
    investments, only after at least 5 percent of the Subsidiary Loan amount has been disbursed
    for subloans to final beneficiaries.

                                  D. APPRAISAL SUMMARY

1. Economic and Financial Analyses
Not applicable.

2. Technical
Not applicable.

3. Fiduciary
Lending will be through an IBRD APL. The Bank's standard fiduciary requirements will apply
to the project and financial intermediaries. Procurement will be in accordance with the Bank
Guidelines for Procurement and for the Use of Consulting Services.

An assessment of the capacity of the Implementing Agency to implement procurement actions
for the project was carried out by Procurement Accredited Specialist (PAS) assigned to the
project during appraisal in February 2006. The assessment reviewed the organizational structure
for implementing the project and the interaction between the project's staff responsible for
procurement and the Ministry's relevant central unit for administration and finance.           The
assessment showed that the PMU had gained adequate experience during the preparation of the
Project to enable it to efficiently carry out the necessary actions and activities to ensure smooth
procurement during Project implementation. It was found that no additional training would be
necessary. Where the Procurement Staff did not have the adequate expertise to carry out
procurement effectively (e.g. Procurement of IT technologies) it is recommended to use the
services of short term specialists. The structure of the proposed Project is such that it is not
necessary that any additional full-time staff be hired.

With the exception of the Credit Line, all procurement activities will be undertaken using the
Bank's current (May 2004) edition of the Procurement and Consultant's Guidelines. Procurement
under the Credit line will be undertaken using established commercial practices acceptable to the
Bank subject to a maximum of US$2 million per contract. These procurements will be carried
out directly by the Beneficiaries and will not involve the PMU.




                                                  17

Based on the financial management assessment of PMU, the financial management arrangements
of the PMU and acceptable and satisfy the Bank's minimum requirements in accordance with
OP/BP 10.02.
The Country Financial Accountability Assessment (CFAA) for Ukraine confirms that
improvement is required in the management of public expenditures, especially for the
strengthening of internal and external audits.

Annual audited financial statements of the project accounts would be provided to the Bank
within six months of the end of each fiscal year and also at the closing of the project. The
project would produce a full set of Financial Monitoring Reports (FMRs) every three months
throughout the life of the project.

Annex 7 and Annex 8 present detailed financial management and procurement arrangements
under the proposed project.

4. Social
The project will have no negative social impact. Proposed investments involving issues of land
acquisition, involuntary resettlement, and possible negative impact on cultural properties,
indigenous peoples, or disputed areas are not eligible for financing under the Project. A Social
Assessment was carried out to explore the current perceived need for rural credit and related
issues, especially among RSMEs, agricultural enterprises and rural entrepreneurs.                             The
assessment found that the demand for rural credit to meet diverse needs was strong among all
farm sizes and businesses. Drawing from the Social Assessment, the key social development
outcomes would be: (a) improved access to reliable financial services by RSMEs; and (b)
increased integration of RSMEs into the market economy.

5. Environment
The Project is classified as a Category "FI". Environmental Assessment policies (OP/BP 4.01)
will apply to the AFSP, including sub-projects.                   In June 2002, the Bank conducted an
Environment Assessment (EA) for Subcomponent A1 of Component A (credit line) to identify
the potential environmental impact from financing agricultural and RSMEs sub-projects. It was
identified that potential sub-loans were not expected to produce any major environmental
impact).17 Given the focus of this project and scope of the sub-projects, it is expected that the
vast majority of sub-projects would fall into Category C.

PB loan officers will review the potential environmental impacts of proposed sub-projects to
ensure their compliance with applicable environmental laws and regulations, and with Bank
environmental safeguard policies. Loan officers will not be environmental specialists, but with
the assistance of an Environmental Guidelines Manual that was prepared, published and
disseminated in June 2003 in English and Ukrainian (updated in February 2006), they will be
able to judge whether or not a particular sub-project would need an environmental assessment
(EA)18 In addition, provision will be included in the project for an environmental specialist to
advise and provide training, if needed, for PMU staff and PBs, to ensure that the environmental


17Copy of the environmental review is included in the project files.
18Environmental screening guidelines, developed during project preparation, are incorporated in the Operations
Manual to be used during project implementation to assist PB loan officers


                                                        18

screening of proposed sub-projects is carried out effectively. The PMU will be responsible for
verifying compliance with these requirements, as part of its project monitoring role. Ex ante
review and clearance by the Bank will be required for any sub-project under Category A of the
Bank guidelines.         During project supervision, the Bank will verify that the environmental
screening of sub-projects is carried out satisfactorily. Annex 10 provides further details.

7. Policy Exceptions and Readiness
No policy exception is needed for the project. The project is ready for implementation, taking
into account preparation support provided from the PPF.




                                                              19

                               Annex 1: Country and Sector Background
                 UKRAINE: ACCESS TO FINANCIAL SERVICES PROJECT

1.      Ukraine, a large central European country of about 48 million people, has a well-
educated, highly skilled labor force.19 An estimated 68 percent of the population lives in urban
areas. Traditionally Ukraine was known as the bread basket of the Soviet Union, however the
contribution of agriculture to GDP has dropped significantly and at the end of 2004 accounted
for only 10.8 percent of GDP. According to the preliminary 2005 results, the share of agriculture
remained at less than 11.5 percent of GDP. Nonetheless, this sector has great potential for
development and a strong need for investment.

2.      Following the Presidential elections at end 2004, the Government launched an ambitious
economic reform agenda, to increase efficiency of the public service, fight corruption, reduce the
shadow economy and enhance public governance and accountability, with the overarching
objective of EU accession. The 2004-2007 Country Assistance Strategy (CAS), updated in July
2005, confirms the Bank's support of the Government's reform agenda and its aspirations to join
the EU by facilitating institutional developments that can lead to a business friendly environment
and a more inclusive and responsive government.                     The CAS is built around seven broad
objectives, including (a) sustainable economic growth with particular emphasis on the
environment for private sector development; (b) poverty reduction and strengthening of the
middle class; and (c) reducing regional imbalances. The proposed project will contribute to
these objectives by providing resources to stimulate the growth of RSMEs and improve the
environment for investment borrowing by SNGs.

Financial Sector

3.      Ukraine's financial sector grew significantly during 2004-2005 to almost 57 percent of
GDP. However it is still dominated by the banking sector which accounts for more than 85
percent of total financial sector assets. The insurance industry is small but dynamic. The
amount of premiums collected, predominantly for non-life insurance, doubled in 2003 and by the
end-2004 reached 5.7 percent of GDP. This percentage dropped to about 5 percent of GDP,
triggered mainly by the strengthening of the prudential regulation aimed at prevention of tax
evasion schemes and capital outflow.                Other non-bank financial institutions (NBFIs) are
underdeveloped, compared to most of the neighboring countries in Central Europe, and account
for less than 1 percent of GDP. The securities market capitalization grew to almost 40 percent of
GDP by the end of 2005. However, the market remains small, fragmented and largely non-
transparent, despite the recent strengthening of securities legislation (passage of the new Law on
Securities and Stock Market) and adoption of the Corporate Governance Code in 2003.
Although there is a strong demand for the services of leasing companies, credit unions and
insurance companies, especially in rural areas and among agricultural producers, the NBFI
services are often underdeveloped and more expensive than banking products.                             While the
legislation for NBFIs is mostly in place, it is often deficient and requires further strengthening
and harmonization.



19Ukraine is divided into 26 regions, with two cities with special status (Kyiv and Sevastopol) and the Autonomous
Republic of Crimea.


                                                         20

4.      Banking Sector. After the fiscal distress of 1998, the banking sector rapidly expanded,
increasing more than 4 times during 2002-2005. Total assets grew from UAH 50.7 billion in
January 2002 to more than UAH 223 billion at the end of 2005, which represents almost 53
percent of GDP. The Ukrainian banking sector has recovered from the end 2004 liquidity crunch,
triggered by the speculation about the vulnerability of the banking system in the midst of the
Orange revolution. In November-December 2004, NBU injected UAH 5.8 billion (5 percent of
the deposit base) into the system to avoid a systemic crisis.20 This mitigated the consequences of
the ceased operations in the interbank market. As a result of the effective measures taken by the
NBU, by early December, the market was functioning, albeit at high overnight interest rates of
20 percent or more for prime banks that had previously borrowed overnight at 5 percent or less
(see Figure 1). By mid-January, market rates had returned to normal, and confidence in the
banking sector was reestablished, as evidenced by the growth in deposits. Corporate and
household deposits reached UAH 133.7 billion (US$26 billion), showing more than 64 percent
growth of deposits in 2005.

             Table 1: Selected Information on the Ukrainian Banking System, 2002-2005
                                                                   2002  2003  2004  2005
            Number of operating banks                              157   157   160   165
            Total assets (UAH billions)                            67.8 100.2 141.4  223
            Total assets as a % of GDP                             30.0  37.5  41.0  52.7
            Net bank assets (adjusted for LLP) as a % of GDP      28.29 38.13  38.9  50.3
            Liabilities, $ bln.                                   11.59 21.40 19.25  42.2
            Equity, $ bln.                                         1.57  2.10  3.14  5.04

            Nominal Growth Rates of Net Banking Assets (%)         34.3  56.9 34.03 59.19
            Loans as % of total assets                               69    70    70  70.1
            Lending to enterprises as % of total lending             82    79    77  69.7
            Lending to private sector, % of GDP                    19.3  26.8  25.6  36.8
            Liquid Assets to Net Assets (percent)                  14.2  16.0  15.2 16.36
            Regulatory Capital to Net Assets (percent)             15.8  13.2 13.53  12.3
            Capital Adequacy Ratio (according to NBU regulations) 18.01 15.11 16.81 14.95

                Source: National Bank of Ukraine

5.      The ten largest banks account for 53.8 percent of total banking sector assets, about 56
percent of total deposits and 43 percent of total capital (Table 2 below). Twenty-seven banks
account for 75.3 percent of the total assets and 77.5 percent of total deposits of the banking
sector. The remaining 138 banks are small and often regarded as "pocket-banks" which serve the
needs of related business groups. The average asset size of a bank increased from US$140
million in 2004 to almost US$268 million in 2005. However Ukrainian banks are still small and
underdeveloped in terms of services and technologies as compared to the leading international
banks. Two banks­Savings (Oschadny) bank and Ukrexim bank­are 100 percent state owned but
have only 9.3 percent share in total banking sector assets.




20Possible because of a high level of international reserves.
