6.       In the second half of 2005 and early 2006, the banking sector saw an active entry of
reputable foreign banks that changed the market landscape and increased competition among the
leading local banks. At end-2005, there were 23 banks with foreign capital, including 9 fully
foreign-owned banks. By May 2006, the share of foreign banks more than doubled to reportedly
more than 25 percent, compared to 11.5 percent at the end of 2004.

                  Table 3. Largest Acquisitions of Ukrainian Banks by Foreign Investors in 2005-2006
                    Bank               % of shares           Foreign buyer                Country
                                           sold

                    Aval                   93.5             Raiffeisen Group               Austria
                    Ukrsotsbank            85.4               Intesa Group                  Italy
                    Ukrsibbank              51               BNP-Paribas                   France
                    Mriya                   98               Vneshtorgbank                 Russia
                    Index                   98              Credit Agricole                France
                    Agio                    98              Vilnusbanka-SEB               Sweden


7.       However, despite the reestablished public confidence in the banking sector and recovery
of the deposit base, Ukrainian banks are still susceptible to liquidity shocks and lack longer term
financing to support medium to longer term investment projects. Rapid development of the
housing finance market and increased investment needs of the Ukrainian enterprises
(metallurgical, manufacturing, chemical and agro-processing) pushed many Ukrainian banks to
the international credit markets. In 2004-2006, several leading Ukrainian banks (Pryvatbank,
UkrEximbank, UkrSibbank) placed almost US$ 800 million in euro bonds.

8.       Financial Sector Regulation. The Laws on National Bank of Ukraine and on Banks and
Banking were passed in 2000 and 2001, respectively. The National Bank of Ukraine (NBU) is
responsible for the regulation of the banking sector. Regulations have been developed over the


                                                        22

last decade and are considered to be relatively modern and comprehensive, albeit with certain
important gaps. These concern mainly transparency of ownership, corporate governance,
classification of assets and hence related lending. However, as is common in most reforming
economies, enforcement needs to be substantially strengthened. The NBU is aware of the need
to further strengthen banking supervision and is upgrading its capacity and legal framework with
TA from the Bank and the IMF as well as from other bilateral and multilateral institutions (US
Treasury, Dutch and French Central banks and EU TACIS).

9.       Banks are regulated and supervised by the Banking Supervision Department (BSD) of the
NBU. Following the 1997 reform of BSD supported by the Bank-supported FSAL project,
NBU's supervisory capacity has been significantly strengthened, legislation streamlined and the
quality of regulations improved. According to the 2002 FSAP findings, Ukraine fully or
materially complied with 16 Basle Core Principles. Between 2003-2005, NBU has undertaken a
number of steps aimed at enhancing quality of banks' reporting and external auditing, disclosure
of information, capitalization and risks management. It is currently preparing a Supervisory
Development Plan (SDP) that will outline actions to be taken to move towards risk-based
supervision and gradual introduction of Basle II requirements. In addition, NBU has submitted to
Parliament amendments to the Law on Banks and Banking aimed at improving corporate
governance of banks, disclosure of information by beneficial/real owners of banks, enforcement
of limitations on insider and related party lending, consolidated reporting and supervision,
improved resolution of problem banks.

10.      The Non-bank Financial Institutions (NBFIs) are regulated by the State Securities
Commission or the State Commission for Regulation of Financial Services Markets (SCRFSM).
The SCRFSM, which was established following the April 2003 Law on Financial Services and
State Regulation of Financial Services Markets, covers insurers, credit unions, non-Government
pension funds, financial leasing and factoring companies, pawnshops, and other financial
institutions. Efforts are needed to ensure that the SCRFSM, as a new institution, has adequate,
skills, funding and legal powers to carry out its mandate in regulating NBFIs.

11.      Leasing. Despite the high demand for capital investments and the need for replacement
of obsolete fixed assets, the leasing industry is seriously underdeveloped. Total lease revenues,
in 2004, were estimated at about 1 percent or less of GDP. Only 20 (including 3 state-owned
companies) of the 40 registered leasing companies are operating. Many leasing companies are
in-house, functioning more as captive finance companies dependent on the cash flow of the
enterprise (or enterprises) they serve. In addition commercial banks have created companies
which mainly provide operating leases on assets they have repossessed. Foreign investors have
recently demonstrated interest in the leasing industry in Ukraine.

12.      Because of deficient legislation, lack of long-term financing and limited knowledge of
service providers, leasing activities focused on installment or deferred sales arrangements rather
than conventional financial leasing. The market for operating leases (mostly for vehicles,




                                                  23

printing, electronics, and some agro-processing equipment) is limited. Financial leases21 were
impractical because of long depreciation schedules and an onerous tax burden.

13.      A revised Law on Financial Leasing, passed in 2004, addressed some of the problems. It
was designed to provide improved terms for financial lease contracts, including changes in
depreciation schedules and contract duration, and thus stimulate the development of a financial
leasing market. Despite these improvements, implementation could be hampered by unfavorable
tax legislation, lack of knowledge, high transaction costs, lack of access to capital markets and,
therefore, uncompetitive cost of funds compared to cheaper bank loans.                           In addition, the
continued presence of the three state leasing companies along with the ambiguous and
discriminatory tax legislation faced by leasing companies relative to banks and insurance
companies could stunt growth in this sector.                 Problems associated with lessor rights and
foreclosure could also hamper the development of the leasing market.22

14.      Credit Unions. According to estimates by the SCRFSM, more than 1000 CUs have been
created in Ukraine since the early 1990s, of which 709 were registered by the SCRFSM as of
October 2006. CUs remain small with estimated total assets of UAH 1.59 billion and more than
1 million members. While the assets of the CUs almost tripled during 2004-2005, this market
still represents only 0.7 percent of banking sector assets. With the exception of the two largest
CUs, the average size of a CU in terms of assets varies between UAH 300,000 to UAH 1 million
(US$60,000 to US$200,000 respectively). The Law on Credit Unions does not allow CUs to
engage in lending to corporate clients, thus CUs operate only with individuals (households and
private entrepreneurs and farmers). Most credit unions are active with consumer and housing
financing in urban areas and CUs cater to the needs of small retail savers and borrowers. Access
to CUs of businessmen and farmers in rural areas is often limited due to the high cost of CU
funds, lack of skills and competition among CUs. As a result, loans to entrepreneurs and farmers
are less than 25-30 percent of the total CUs' credit portfolio.

15.      In recent years, CUs have faced increasing competition from commercial banks. This has
led to an initiative to expand the activities of the CUs to allow them to lend to corporate clients
as well as take deposits from non-members. However, this reform is pending, owing to limited
skills and capacity of CUs in the area of corporate lending, risk and liquidity management.

16.      The market is undergoing significant reconfiguration. A National Credit Union
Association (NACSU) was established in 1995 and has more than 140 member CUs with a total
membership of over 130,000. It monitors and self regulates the performance of its members.
However, NACSU is dominated by, and caters mainly to, a number of large credit unions which
are more retail oriented. This has led to the formation (largely by rural CUs) of 16 regional
credit union associations. There is a need for NACSU to revise its membership and voting

21 The fundamental differences between an operating and financial lease are the treatment of ownership and
depreciation. Most financial leases include an option to purchase and, generally, the lessee can deduct depreciation
for tax purposes.
22An IFC 2003 leasing industry analysis identified several problems preventing leasing from becoming a viable
financing instrument, including: (a) complicated and lengthy process to repossess assets; (b) ambiguous laws and
regulations which invite bureaucratic discretion and, thus, uncertainty; and (c) tax rules that makes depreciation of
leased assets longer than their normal economic life, and thus implies excessive taxation. IFC is expected to provide
technical assistance to help address some of the shortcomings.


                                                         24

structure and to strengthen its corporate governance so that it can better serve the needs on a
countrywide basis, including rural areas. Two other national associations have been created
more recently but are not yet fully operational.

17.      CU Legal and Supervisory Framework. The Law on Credit Unions, enacted in January
2002, defines credit unions as nonprofit, cooperative organizations.23                 The law introduces
regulatory requirements for CUs and, together with the 2001 Law on Financial Services and
State Regulation of Financial Services Markets, mandates their regulation and prudential
supervision by SCRFSM. Creation of a CU requires minimum 50 members. The same applies for
the creation of a cooperative bank. The minimum statutory capital requirement for a bank is
Euro 1 million for a regional cooperative bank and Euro 5 million for a nationwide cooperative
bank. So far, no cooperative bank has been established by the CU community, despite several
attempts. Credit unions have established the Central Credit Union (CCU) which could be treated
as a bank of credit unions. However, the CCU does not have a banking license and provides
basic finance for the CUs which are members of NACSU. Other CUs plan to create an
alternative CCU. However, its further operations will be constrained unless respective changes
are introduced to both the Law on Credit Unions and Law on Banks and Banking Activity in
Ukraine.

18.      Housing finance. This market has grown rapidly in the last several years and has
substantial potential for further development. Until 2005, most housing construction, primarily
in Kyiv, was financed by bank "Arkada" and/or outside the banking system (on an equity basis
or through contractual investment schemes). Some programs (such as provision of housing for
young families, military and civil servants) was and, on a limited basis is still, supported by the
Government. In 2005, mortgage financing increased almost 3.5 times and reached 2.5 percent of
GDP. The share of residential housing finance increased to 1.6 percent of GDP from 0.6 percent
in 2004. More commercial banks launched mortgage lending, while the core thirteen banks
control 78 percent of the residential housing mortgage financing market.

19.      The Law on Mortgage, drafted with assistance from the PPF, became effective on
January 1, 2004. It conforms with modern international standards and is one of the most liberal
and progressive in the region. For the market to realize the positive impact of this law, more
work needs to be undertaken to ensure its harmonization with other legislation. To allow
mortgage refinancing and develop mortgage bonds market, in December 2005 the Parliament of
Ukraine passed the Law on Mortgage Bonds as was recommended by the Bank, IFC and other
Donors (EBRD, USAID, EU TACIS). While this law has several weaknesses, it establishes a
basic framework for the issue and circulation of conventional covered (mortgage) bonds and
allows securitization of mortgage assets. The implementation of the law will require significant
effort of the Ukrainian regulators, especially the State Commission for Securities and Stock
Market, to put proper regulations in place to ensure compliance with the legal requirements by
the bonds' issuers, including disclosure of information to potential buyers of the mortgage bonds.




23The Law requires that CUs have at least 50 members who share a common feature, such as the same workplace or
place of residence. CUs may offer services only to members and loans typically range from US$20 to US$3,000.
No loan can exceed 20 percent of the CUs' total capital.


                                                        25

20.      To support liquidity of the mortgage market and provide refinancing to banks, in
November 2004, the Government established the State Mortgage Institution (SMI) with a
statutory capital of UAH 20 million. In 2005, the Parliament approved an increase of SMI's
capital to UAH 100 million.

21.      The SMI is expected to operate initially as a liquidity facility, with potential future
expansion of its services once it has developed adequate management, skills and procedures.
Substantial support will be needed to ensure that government housing policies do not undermine
market practices and that the SMI operates in accordance with prudent financial practices. This
would require that the Government reconsider its proposed strategy for subsidized mortgage
finance to ensure that it does not distort the market. The Bank has provided extensive advice to
the Government on the issues of SMI operations, including the pre-conditions for the use of the
state guarantee to support the issue of SMI's bonds. The policy dialogue and appropriate
conditionality is being conducted under the Development Policy Loan (DPL) series. Any support
to be provided under the project will be consistent with this dialogue.

Enabling Infrastructure

22.      Ukraine has made progress in strengthening its financial sector framework. In addition to
the financial sector legislation mentioned above, a number of laws have been enacted to help
protect creditors' rights, as well as to further develop the financial market and its contribution to
private sector growth. Law on Real Estate Title and Registration of Land (2004), Law on
Mortgage (2003), Law on Warehouse Receipts (2004). However, as in many other transition
economies, implementation of the laws is weak and enforcement is often hampered by
deficiencies in the operations the legal and judicial systems.

23.      Registration of Charges. Following passage of the 1999 Law on Pledge, the Register of
private pledges was established. It is maintained by the Information Center of the Ministry of
Justice and operated by independent registrars (predominantly commercial banks and notaries).
Law on Security of Creditors Rights and Registration of Charges, passed in 2003, removes the
inequality between public and private creditors and introduces the principle of "first-come, first-
served" in establishing security interests. Public pledges (mainly those established by the State
Tax Administration) were introduced to the Register in 2002. The Register will be expanded to
accommodate the change in the law and to allow the registration of new types of assets covered
by the law.24 The Information Center of the Ministry of Justice is committed to upgrade the
Register and promote establishment of the necessary revised registration procedures.

24.      Credit Information Bureau. NBU maintains a register of the largest non-performing
borrowers but this does not fully meet the needs of the financial sector. To address this need,
following the passage of the Law on Organizing of Information and Circulation of Credit
Histories in 2004, the banking community, with the support of the NBU, decided to establish the
First All-Ukrainian Credit Information Bureau (FAUCIB) in mid-2005. Almost 30 banks and


24Assets such as livestock, machinery, and standing crops are not yet widely used as collateral because of the
continued weaknesses in application of or gaps in the existing legal framework for the creation, registration,
enforcement of secured interests in movable property, and the lack of a viable resale market for repossessed assets.
In addition, lenders are hesitant to lend against collateral such as receivables and inventory.


                                                             26

several insurance companies are shareholders of the FAUCIB. This entity is expected to collect
both positive and negative credit histories on indebtedness of borrowers, including individuals
and SMEs, in line with the EU Directive on Protection of Personal Information and in
accordance with the best international practices. It expects to cover the needs of about 60 percent
of the banking market and insurance sector. Recently, FAUCIB has announced a tender for the
selection of a business and investment partner from among the leading international credit
bureaus. Another two credit bureaus were established recently in Ukraine, but none of them is
yet operational.

Target Beneficiaries

25.     Rural Small and Medium Enterprises. SMEs25 contribute significantly to employment
and GDP, and provide the only employment and income source to many poor households.
Attention to their development is therefore essential for economic growth and poverty reduction.
The share of the SME sector in Ukraine's GDP is only 8 percent but it employs 21 percent of the
labor force (Table 5 shows some comparator countries). At the lower end of SME sector is a
mixture of the self-employed and "micro" enterprises, with less than 10 employees. A significant
proportion of these enterprises are found in the informal sector.

       Table 5: SME Indicators in Selected Countries (Excluding Entrepreneurs with No Employees)
                                             Ukraine1   Russia2    Kazakhstan    4   France5         Italy5
                   Indicators
                                               2003       2002         2003            2004           2004
    Population Employed in SMEs (%)            21%        20%           7%             57%            71%
    SME Contribution to GDP (%)                 8%        11%          13%             50%            55%
    1Statistics Directorate; Russian SME Support Agency; Ministry of Statistics and Analysis of Belarus
                            2                             3

    4Based on Statistics Agency of Kazakhstan data; Fifth All-Russian Conference of Small Businesses, 2004
                                                   5



26.     The 2002 reform of state collective farms resulted in reorganization and/or liquidation of
almost 15,000 large public agricultural production enterprises. This led to the creation of about
45,000 new farmer enterprises and growth of rural SMEs. Many of these new enterprises
required significant capital to be able to purchase production equipment and replace obsolete
machinery, and as a result create employment opportunities for hundreds thousands of rural
citizens who have lost their job in the process of the state farms reform. Overall limited access
to credit of the newly established enterprises has significantly hampered the performance and
growth of the RSMEs.

27.     About 5.6 million people are employed in the agricultural sector, representing almost 20
percent of the labor force of Ukraine. Agricultural production contributes to nearly 12 percent of
GDP. Almost 60 percent of agricultural production is attributed to households, and the remaining
40 percent is produced by the agricultural enterprises.




25In Ukraine, SMEs are enterprises with 11-250 employees. At the lower end, is a mixture of the self-employed and
"micro" enterprises, with less than 10 employees.



                                                     27

                                                    index insurance, as they are not covered by subsidies.
and private agricultural enterprises, the
Government passed several new laws and amended existing acts to establish a more conducive
environment for the development of agricultural business. This legislation includes a law on
warehouse receipts, special tax treatment of agricultural producers and private entrepreneurs
(including single tax for SMEs), compensations for cattle-farmers. The Government also
envisages reforms aimed at harmonization of Ukrainian legislation with WTO requirements.

29.     Sub-national Governments. The 1997 "Law on Local Self-Government in Ukraine"
developed the organizational and legal basis for local governments (including division of
functions for each level of government), and established the legal basis for SNG borrowing
(Figure 6 shows the various types of SNGs). The Budget Code of Ukraine (2001), drafted with
the assistance from the PPF, establishes the basis for a formula driven intergovernmental transfer
system and significantly clarifies revenue sources and functions for each level of government.
When introduced, this formula, together with the elimination of soft inter-budgetary loans,
should represent a significant step towards more objective and transparent rules for local
government financing.

30.     While there is a basic framework in place, the legal framework for SGN borrowing and
SGN debt remains dispersed and, in some instances, internally inconsistent. Although almost all
SNGS have enormous investment needs to upgrade infrastructure and services, under current
legislation, only the Autonomous Republic of Crimea (ARC), the municipal governments of
major cities (and their municipal utilities with a guarantee from their respective municipality to
borrow) are allowed to have a capital budget deficit. Thus, other SNGs (oblasts, rayons, town,
villages and settlements) cannot borrow, except to cover current budget cash gaps.




26Ukraine's agricultural potential is significantly underutilized. Investment in agriculture as a percentage of total
investment declined sharply during the 1990's, from 21.3 percent in 1990 to 2.1 percent in 2002.


                                                          28

                          Figure 6: Administrative-Territorial Structure of Ukraine

                                       City of         Oblasts (24)
                       ARC            Sevastopol                       City of Kyiv



                                              Cities of             Rayons
                                               Oblasts              (490)
                                                (176)



                                                 Towns              Villages       Settlements
                                                 (314)              (28,651)         (893)




31.     Deficiencies in the legal framework combined with the negative experience of a default
by the city of Odessa on bonds it issued in 1998 reduce the willingness of the private sector to
lend to SNGs. Private sector credit is limited to the largest SNGs in the country, and with short
terms and high rates of real interest. Nonetheless, a group of large banks in the country are
beginning to expand their lending, primarily to the utility companies27 against physical collateral
and with the guarantee of the municipality that owns them.

32.     To improve access to finance for SNG, a number of steps need to be taken, including: (a)
passage of a comprehensive legislation for SNG debt and guarantees; (b) reassessment of
functions and their division among various levels of the government; (c) improving the formula-
based transfer system; and (d) establishing a modern debt monitoring system on the level of the
Central Government (in the Ministry of Finance) as well as SNGs.

Factors that Limit Access to Credit

33.     Constraints on both the supply and demand sides limit access to credit, especially by
RSMEs and SNGs. More effective intermediation would foster private sector development and
contribute to sustained economic growth. The most important constraints impeding access to
credit by RSMEs and SNGs include the following:

    (i)  Lack of long-term funding. Banks do not have access to long-term funds and the bulk of
        their liabilities are demand deposits. Short-term lending (3-6 months) accounts for 70
        percent of banks' aggregate loan portfolio and almost all loans with maturities of more
        than one year are financed by international sources.
    (ii) Banks have high operating costs. This translates into high margins and lending rates.
        The high rates could lead to adverse selection by becoming too expensive for sound
        enterprises to borrow, so that most lending is made for riskier undertakings/borrowers.
        This could in turn lead to a poor quality loan portfolio and high provisions, causing a


27Municipal utilities are defined in the law "On Local Governments of Ukraine" as municipal utility companies
owned by the community they serve. These companies face the same access to investment capital issues as RSMEs
and SNGs.


                                                       29

     vicious circle as banks will reflect their increase costs in higher margins. The high cost
     and short maturity of loans discourage potential borrowers from applying for loans.
(iii) Credit underwriting skills are underdeveloped. Banks have not invested in developing
     the systems required to serve retail clients. The banks to date have focused largely on
     relationship lending, making decisions on the basis of direct contacts and knowledge of
     the borrower, which in many cases may have a controlling interest in the lending bank.
     In particular, banks make little use of transaction-based lending technologies such as:
     financial statement lending, small business credit scoring, asset-based lending, factoring
     and leasing.
(iv) Weak lending infrastructure, particularly lack of information on the repayment history
     of borrowers and poor accounting and auditing practices. The financial infrastructure is
     insufficiently developed to aid financial intermediaries in their assessment and
     mitigation of risk, for example, inadequate information on the repayment history of
     borrowers (through well functioning credit bureaus, credit rating agencies and secured
     transactions registry for movable property).        The financial position of potential
     borrowers, especially in rural areas, is difficult to ascertain due to unreliable financial
     reporting (financial statements are prepared primarily for tax purposes and are not
     consistent with International Standards of Financial Reporting - IFRS).
(v) An inadequate legal and judicial framework provides weak protection of creditors'
     rights resulting in excessive requirements for collateral (that makes it difficult for SMEs
     to borrow) and a costly dispute resolution process that increases the cost of lending.
(vi) Banks have underdeveloped branch networks. The absence of local branches and lack
     of availability of information on clients outside main urban areas make creditworthiness
     more difficult to assess and hence lending more costly. An increased presence of the
     larger banks throughout the country could increase lending to RSMEs and SNGs.
(vii) Lending to SNGs presents additional constraints and risks. With the exception of short-
     term borrowing for budget deficit financing, there is no significant local government
     borrowing outside Kyiv. This situation hinders the ability of the central government to
     decentralize important parts of local public service delivery. Furthermore, lack of
     access to financial services limits the provision and coverage of local services that SNGs
     provide, since they are unable to finance the capital costs required to upgrade or expand
     infrastructure networks. Lack of a SNG credit market, in short, is preventing the
     development of a public finance system that assigns significant decision-making power
     and financing responsibility to SNGs. The existing legal framework for SNG borrowing
     does not comprehensively and consistently address the issues related to SNG debt.
     Relevant rules are largely indirect, scattered among various laws, decrees and
     regulations or established on an informal basis.          In several instances, they are
     inconsistent, incomplete or ambiguous, further exacerbating the legal uncertainty for
     SNG lending.
(viii)The size and presence of non-bank lenders is negligible. Non-bank intermediation, such
     as through leasing companies and credit unions, is low due mainly to the lack of an
     appropriate legal framework.




                                              30

Government Strategy for Improving Access to Credit

34.     The Ukrainian authorities have designed a program aimed at increasing overall access to
credit markets with special focus on RMSEs and SNGs, which are located at the fringes of the
financial sector. The strategy is predicated on the idea that credit markets must be built in two
directions. First from the top down, in terms of a legal and policy framework that will support
efficient credit market operations. And second from the bottom up, in terms of practical
experience for banks and other lenders in making loans to the clienteles with limited access
today. Both tracks, namely building a supportive legal and policy framework and accumulating
practical experience in RSMEs and SNGs lending are envisioned to move forward
simultaneously under the program.

35.     The following will be the public policy intervention supported by the program: (a)
assisting the banking sector to develop the capacity to provide retail financial services, in order
to reduce the transaction costs gap between lenders and potential borrowers; (b) enhancing the
protection of creditors rights to lessen the risk of lending to potential borrowers; (c) building the
credit market infrastructure and new financial products to make credit transactions more
attractive to both borrowers and lenders; (d) providing technical assistance to SNGs aimed at
preparing bankable credit proposals and business plans; and (d) making available a
comparatively modest amount of well-targeted and properly priced long term credit funds to
trigger implementation of the program and promote rapid market take up of the opportunities
thereby created.

36.     To bring about this new vision, the Government strategy includes:

         ·   Providing banks access to long-term resources for on-lending to RSMEs and SNGs.
         ·   Assisting financial intermediaries expand their network of branches in rural areas
             and acquire the lending technologies suitable for lending to RSMEs and SNGs.
         ·   Upgrading the lending infrastructure (policy, legal, regulatory and institutional) to
             stimulate the development of the financial services market.




                                                  31

                                                                           Attachment to Annex 1

                                     Unofficial Translation

Mr. Shigeo Katsu
Regional Vice President
Europe and Central Asia
The World Bank
Washington, DC

Dear Mr. Katsu,

                Re: Access to Financial Services Adaptable Program Loan (APL)

        On behalf of the Government of Ukraine, I am pleased to use this opportunity to brief
you about Ukraine's continuing successful economic development, and commitment to
implementing programs which will ensure sustainable economic growth with emphasis on
private sector development, strengthening of the middle class, reducing regional imbalances, and
poverty reduction. We believe a key contributing factor to achieving the above objectives is
improving access to financial services particularly in the rural areas of Ukraine.

        Ukraine enjoyed high rates of economic growth in the recent past. Improved financial
discipline, more prudent fiscal and monetary policies and improvement of the business climate,
have all contributed to this good performance. The good fortunes, however, have been mainly
concentrated in large financial-industrial groups able to take advantage of growth opportunities
in the export market due to their integration with the banking sector. In contrast, rural and small
and medium enterprises (RSMEs) have had limited access to credit, restricting the extent to
which they have been able to benefit from increasing domestic and export market opportunities.
Similarly, sub-national governments (SNGs) and utilities, have had limited access to long-term
funds to meet their capital investment needs.

        The development of rural finance has been a key priority for consecutive governments of
Ukraine. In this context, we have designed a program aimed at increasing overall access to
credit markets with special focus on RMSEs and SNGs. This strategy recognizes that to be
successful, legal, policy, and institutional environment/ framework need to be conducive to
efficient credit market operations. Additionally, under the program, given the current lack of
long-term financial resources, the Government is committed to helping jumpstart the process
through providing long-term funds at market rates to the banking community and other lenders to
engage with the above clients, with current limited access to credit, and gain expertise and
comfort in such transactions in the long term.

        Achievements to date, including those with the support of the Project Preparation
Facility (PPF), the Bank and the other donors

        In the course of implementation of the financial sector development strategy, with the
support of the Access to Financial Services PPF and with active involvement of the World Bank
experts, we have achieved important results to date towards establishment of the appropriate


                                                32

environment for increased financial intermediation in Ukraine. The most important of them are
briefly outlined below.

A. In the sphere of rural finance

        In December 2005 the Government of Ukraine adopted the Concept of the Complex
Program of Support for Development of Ukrainian Rural Areas for the period of 2006-2010. The
implementation of the Program shall be conducted through improvement of organizational and
economic mechanisms as well as enhancement of state support of rural development.

        The Program focuses on a number of crucial areas of rural finance and its implementation
envisages special efforts of the Government towards establishing conducive institutional and
legal framework for rural development. This include, for example, development of legislation
and new financial instruments aimed at (i) reduction of risks inherent to agribusiness finance and
promotion of efficient agribusiness development, (ii) establishment of modern warehouses
receipts system, (iii) risks-mitigation in lending to agribusinesses and use of modern hedging and
insurance instruments, including index insurance and mutual insurance products. The Program
specifies directions of financial and investment support for rural businesses, such as
improvement of tax regimes and tax policies for agriculture, reform of state support for rural
development and agricultural production in line with the best international practices and WTO
requirements. It also supports development of financial intermediaries (banks and non-bank
credit institutions, including credit cooperatives) and introduction of new financial instruments,
such as insurance for rural businesses.

B. In the sphere of mortgage finance

        Significant progress has been achieved in formulating the Government strategy and
creating basic legal framework for the development of mortgage finance market in recent years.
Specifically, the Law on Mortgage came into force on January 1, 2004. The Concept Paper for
development of Mortgage Finance Market was endorsed by the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine
in June 2004. With the support of the Access to Financial Services PPF the Government has
developed necessary documents and analysis that led to create the State Mortgage Institution
(SMI) ­ the 2nd tier mortgage finance intermediary aimed at providing refinancing to the primary
mortgage lenders, necessary to support their liquidity and promote housing finance in Ukraine.
Draft business plan and development strategy for the SMI were also developed within the Project
preparation. In addition, in December 2005 the Parliament of Ukraine has adopted the new Law
on Mortgage Bonds which came into force in 2006. The Law defines the legal framework for
issuance and circulation of mortgage bonds, as well as requirements for securitization of
mortgages. The Law also defines the requirements for disclosure of information, protection of
investors' rights and regulation of activities of the issuers of mortgage bonds.

        Establishment and development of an efficient and full-functioning system of mortgage
finance in Ukraine in conformity with the best international standards, is one of the priorities of
the Government`s economic policy. Operation of this system will foster solution of a number of
social and economic problems. Of 165 banks operating in Ukraine at the end of 2005, some 35
banks dominated mortgage finance market, with 13 of them controlling more than 78% of the
housing finance products. During the period of 2004-2005, mortgage financing increased



                                                   33

significantly. In 2005, it expanded 3.38 times and reached UAH 10.6 billion or 2.5% of GDP.
While the existing level of mortgage lending in Ukraine is much lower than in most developed
and Central European countries, the evolution of the mortgage finance market is promising.

        Despite the above developments, many factors could hamper the long-term sustainable
growth of mortgage financing in Ukraine, including:

    ·   inadequate and in some areas inconsistent legislative and regulatory framework in the
        sphere of mortgage financing;
    ·   ineffective system of refinancing of primary mortgage creditors;
    ·   maturities mismatch between assets and liabilities of commercial banks, stemming from
        the lack of access to long-term financial resources;
    ·   limited diversification of financial resources and their relatively high cost;
    ·   substantial credit, currency and interest rate risks of mortgage creditors;
    ·   absence of credit histories of borrowers and complexity in credit scoring and assessment
        of the creditworthiness of borrowers;
    ·   rapid growth of real estate housing prices and non-transparent distribution of land for
        housing construction that reduces the supply of housing for sale.

C. In the sphere of financial services in general

        The Government of Ukraine is undertaking large-scale efforts to reform and enhance the
financial services markets. Substantial progress has been achieved to date in development of the
banking sector and strengthening quality of banking supervision. In 2005, the assets of the
banking sector grew by about 60 percent and by the end of 2005 reached UAH 223 billion
(slightly more than US$44 billion). After 1998, Ukrainian banking sector rapidly expanded and
increased by more than 3.5 times during 2002-2005. Almost 71 percent of banks' assets are
invested into loans. Corporate and household deposits in banks reached UAH 133.7 billion
(US$26.5 billion) by the end of 2005, showing almost 65% growth in 2005 despite the run on
deposits at the end of 2004. Banks have significantly increased retail lending and the growing
presence of reputable foreign banks will provide additional impetus for expansion of banking
activities and increasing competition in the sector. Banking supervision department of the
National Bank of Ukraine has approved Supervisory Development Plan that envisions further
strengthening of banking legislation and regulation and gradual introduction of risks-based
supervision as well as Basle 2.

        To achieve broad objectives of financial sector reform, the Government of Ukraine has
recently commissioned preparation of the Financial Sector Development Strategy for 2006-2015.
The special working group was set up under the auspices of the State Commission for Regulation
of Financial Services Markets (the NBFI regulator), comprising of the representatives of the
financial regulation authorities of Ukraine, including NBFI regulator, National Bank of Ukraine
and Securities and Stock Market State Commission.

        Besides the recent initiative to prepare the comprehensive strategy for the development of
Ukraine's financial sector, the Government already adopted sector specific strategies and concept
documents in the spheres of insurance, pension system, stock markets, financial monitoring and
anti-money laundering. Specifically, in August 2005 the Government approved the Concept for


                                                  34

Development of Insurance Market for the period till 2010. The concept support a number of
objectives in development of insurance market, aimed at creating sound protection of property
interests of individuals and corporations, development of modern market mechanisms for
attracting investments into national economy, secured by efficient functioning of insurance
services market. The implementation of the insurance market envisions strengthening of
insurance legal and regulatory framework, application of best international practices in provision
of life and non-life insurance services, and revision of tax legislation for insurance. In addition,
development of insurance market will also depend on creation of sound financial market
infrastructure, enhanced powers of the regulator and protection of interests of the consumers, as
well as development of new insurance and financial instruments. In November 2005, the
President of Ukraine has also endorsed the guidelines for the future development of the capital
markets in Ukraine. Moreover, in cooperation with commercial banks the National Bank of
Ukraine has prepared and sent for discussion the draft Strategy for Development of the banking
sector of Ukraine for 2006-2010.

D. In the sphere of Cooperative Finance

        Significant efforts have been undertaken to develop Ukraine's cooperative finance
system. With the support of the Access to Financial Services PPF, the NBFI Regulator in
cooperation with local and international experts is drafting the Concept for the Development of
Credit Cooperation System in Ukraine. The Concept will be adopted in 2006. Currently,
cooperative finance market has several levels and comprises of credit unions at the local level,
joint (central) credit unions at the regional or national level, regional and national professional
associations. As of December 2005 there were 715 credit unions registered in Ukraine, including
4 joint credit unions. The membership of credit unions exceeds 1 million people. At the end of
2005 there were 17 regional associations, covering more than 300 credit unions. There are also
three national associations, with National Association of Credit Unions (NACSU) representing
more than 140 credit unions. There is a continued tendency for increased activities of the credit
unions in the market, although their share in the total assets of the financial sector does not
exceed 2 percent. However, the sector is steadily developing, as evidenced by the growth of the
assets: for the last 24 months total assets of credit unions more than tripled and as of end 2005
reached almost UAH 2 billion. Structure and quality of the CUs` assets also improved, along
with the growth of their share capital

        As credit unions service those categories of clients which normally lack attention of
banks (such as vulnerable groups of population with low income and people in rural areas), they
will become an important element of rural finance system and social support mechanism in
Ukraine. Despite of recent positive trends in development of financial markets, cooperative
finance system requires State's support and significant improvements in the areas of legal and
regulatory framework, institutional capacity and infrastructure of cooperative finance market,
aimed at protecting the rights of CUs` members and facilitating their development in accordance
with the best international practices.




                                                 35

E. In the sphere of inter-budgetary relations and financing of Sub-National Governments
(SNGs) and municipal enterprises.

        Enhancement of financial foundations and improvement of inter-budgetary relations are
important factors for local and regional development. Through the adoption of the Budgetary
Code in 2001 the revenues and expenditures of State and local governments budgets were
separated, relevant principles established and the mechanism for inter-budgetary transfers
launched. The Budgetary Code incorporated new principles of structuring and functioning of the
budgetary system of the State, foremost in the sphere of inter-budgetary relations.

        The Budgetary Code stipulates for a new approach towards inter-budgetary relations:
relations between the State and local budgets become more transparent. The new methodology
for local budget planning was introduced, the overall volume of local budgets increased, role and
functions of local governments in the budgetary process become more clear-cut. After applying
formula approach to calculation of inter-budgetary transfers, the level of differentiation in
financing social services on the regional level decreased. Finally, a draft law On Local
Borrowings and the State Guarantees is currently being reviewed by the Government for
submission to the Parliament.

        Nevertheless, the overall situation with the local budgets remains complicated. Among
the main problems are: absence of adequate legal framework for SNG borrowing, significant
differentiations in revenues and expenditures of local budgets (on inter-and intra- regional level);
weak financial management and forecasting of local budget revenues leading to poor justification
and projection of income of local budgets; lack of adequate legislation and regulations for
managing inter-budgetary relations and mutual transfers etc. Therefore, the budgetary system of
Ukraine needs further improvement and adjustment to the best international principles in order to
support efficient regional and local development.

        Future Program

        The Government of Ukraine resolutely implements the policies towards adoption of the
best international principles and accession to the global financial markets and international
organizations, including WTO. Within such policies the Government is committed to adhere to
the rules, policies and standards of state support and market liberalization, including in the areas
of regulatory policies, which are envisioned by international agreements, including WTO
Agreement on Agriculture, GATT, Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Duties etc. In
the sphere of financial services, Ukraine has pronounced clear reform agenda based on
introduction of international best standards and practices in legislative, regulatory and
institutional framework. This will allow to ensure stable development of financial institutions in
line with the sound practices of risks management and disclosure of information; to establish
efficient system of micro and cooperative finance to develop new financial services and make
financial institutions more efficient and competitive. These reforms will be supported by the
increased capitalization of the financial institutions and entry of foreign capital, both into the
banking and insurance sector in the upcoming years.

        1. Mortgage Finance. The Government will support establishment of an efficient and
transparent two-tier mortgage finance system in line with the best international standards and



                                                36

practices based on the market principles. Future developments in the sphere of mortgage
finance, as conceived by the policy instruments adopted by the Government, will be aimed at
harmonization of mortgage finance legislation and removal of existing inconsistencies,
enhancement of transparency and consumer protection in the mortgage finance market,
unification and increased efficiency of the real estate and mortgage registration system,
standardization of the mortgage lending procedure according to the best practices, development
of proper procedure for assessment of creditworthiness of the mortgage borrowers, monitoring of
the quality of mortgage portfolio and risks management of primary mortgage lenders. To
facilitate further development of the mortgage finance market and support liquidity of the
mortgage lenders, the Government has committed to ensure development of the State Mortgage
Institution (SMI) as a liquidity facility that provides refinancing to primary mortgage lenders on
the basis of transparent, commercially viable, profitable, and low risk operations.

        Specifically, the Government stands ready to facilitate future sound development of SMI
by (i) ensuring its sound corporate governance; (ii) facilitating engagement of best expertise
(international and local experts) necessary to prepare adequate regulations and procedures for
operations of SMI; (iii) providing guidance and applying best international practices in
developing SMI's documents such as business and financial plans, internal policies and risks
management procedures, IT/MIS etc, necessary to bring SMI's operations in line with the
pronounced principles and make it competitive and efficient.

        Moreover, future development of mortgage finance market will be in line with the
provisions of the COM Resolution #559-p on the Concept for Development of the Mortgage
Market in Ukraine which outlines clear principles of non-government intervention, application of
good international practices, and introduction of the conductive legal and regulatory framework
and market practices necessary to develop competitive, transparent and accessible mortgage
finance in Ukraine.

        2. Insurance Sector. In insurance sector, according to the Concept for the development of
insurance market in Ukraine till 2010 (approved by the Resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers of
Ukraine in August 2005), a number of the reforms will be implemented along inter alia the
following lines:

    -   implementation of efficient state regulation and supervision in the insurance sphere in the
        light of best international practices and standards recommended by International
        Association of Insurance Supervisors;

    -   development of long-term life insurance, enhancement of insurers participation in private
        pension systems and establishment of regulation of insurers activities in the sphere of
        mandatory health insurance;

    -   increased capitalization, soundness and trustworthiness of insurance companies;

    -   improvement of the tax regime of the insurance activities.

        The implementation of the concept will be conducted according to the annual action plans
to be developed by the NBFI Regulator in cooperation with other financial regulators, Ministry
of Economy, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Justice and League of Insurance Companies.


                                                  37

       3. Cooperative Finance. According to the Concept being currently developed by the
NBFI Regulator, the main objective of developing sound credit cooperation system is formation
of the efficient market mechanisms for expanding access to finance and provision of alternative
financial services to population, small businesses and farmers. Development of vibrant
cooperative finance system along with commercial banking services will allow Ukraine to
establish adequate conditions for long-term financing, using modern market infrastructure and
financial instruments allowing for decrease of cost of financial resources for entrepreneurs and
SME, especially in rural areas.

     State policy in this area envisions indirect Government influence of future development of
the sector by improving legal framework (Law on Credit Unions), enhancing regulation and
supervision of credit unions and bringing it in line with international principles, as well as
promoting and assisting in establishment of efficient market infrastructure.


       4. Reforms in the Banking Sector. The National Bank of Ukraine proclaimed its intention
to support the following directions of the banking sector development:

       ·   raising the level of capitalization of the banking sector;
       ·   increasing the quality and competitiveness of banking services;
       ·   enforcing international standards of corporate governance and disclosure of
           information, including information about real (beneficial owners of banks);
       ·   further development of risks management in banks;
       ·   improving protection of the rights of creditors and depositors.

       These objectives are defined and supported by the reform measures in the draft Strategy
for the Development of the Banking Sector during 2006­2010 which was prepared by the
National Bank of Ukraine jointly with the Association of Ukrainian Banks and market
participants. It aims at developing stable, transparent, and competitive banking system in
Ukraine, which would promote long-term economic growth of the country, its financial security,
and be capable and prepared to integrate into the world economic space without detriment to
national interests. This strategy is supported by the respective reforms in the area of banking
supervision and commitment of Ukraine to bring revisions to the Ukrainian banking legislation,
necessary to harmonize it with EU legislation and recommendations of Basle Committee for
Banking Supervision.

       5. Access to finance for SNGs. The system of inter-budgetary relations remains imperfect.
Primarily mechanisms of allocation of inter-budgetary transfers require reforming.
Differentiation between regions based on volumes of tax revenue per capita is over 11 times.
Relevant differences are being compensated by the existing system of transfers that does not
stimulate the local government to foster the increase in tax revenue. It is deemed necessary to
introduce new system of earmarked transfers, and their channeling to solve concrete social and
economic issues.

       Within the Project the implementation of measures aimed at reforming local inter-
budgetary relations and improvement of regulatory and legal framework of local borrowings will
be conducted along the following lines:


                                                  38

            -   optimization of allocation of competence between executive bodies of
                different levels and local government;
            -   development of the formula-based model of inter-budgetary transfers as well
                as improvement of methodology for projecting incomes of local government
                and calculating of expenditure limits;
            -   development and installation of software to improve the local debt monitoring
                system;
            -   improvement of legal framework for local borrowings and local debt
                monitoring system.

        The phases of APL, their proposed design, and how they are linked to the current
achievement and future plans

        We request the World Bank to support our Program through implementation of two
phases of the Access to Financial Services Project.

        Together with your staff, we have identified the following key project performance
indicators which would function as triggers for consideration of the second phase of the APL:

   ·    at least 60 percent of the line of credit provided under the first APL is disbursed;
   ·    less than 5 percent of the average outstanding sub-loans are classified (substandard,
        doubtful and loss);
   ·    A satisfactory legal and regulatory framework is in place for leasing, factoring and credit
        unions (for these institutions to be included in APL2);
   ·    A satisfactory framework for SNG borrowing is in place, including: (a) the law on SNG
        borrowing; (b) a functioning SNG debt monitoring system at the MoF; (c) clear definition
        of functional assignments and their financing for different levels of government; and (d)
        adequate local government accounting and reporting systems;
   ·    The Government has refrained from making credit lines available on terms and
        conditions representing unfair competition to the credit and leasing facilities financed
        under the program.

        The Program support includes: (a) assisting the banking sector to develop the capacity to
provide retail financial services, in order to reduce the transaction costs gap between lenders and
potential borrowers; (b) enhancing the protection of creditors rights to lessen the risk of
intermediation; (c) building up the credit market infrastructure and new financial products to
make credit transactions more attractive to both borrowers and lenders; (d) providing technical
assistance to SNGs aimed at preparing bankable credit proposals and business plans; and (e)
making available a comparatively modest amount of well-targeted and properly priced long term
credit funds to trigger implementation of the program and promote rapid market take up of the
opportunities thereby created.

        Final outcomes expected and conclusions




                                                   39

       The implementation of the proposed Program will substantially contribute to the success
of the mentioned above development policies. Thus far the Government expects that Program
implementation will produce the following results:

    -  providing access to long-term and reasonably priced loans by individuals, agricultural
       producers and other undertakings;

    -  capacity development of financial markets infrastructure;

    -  improving the legislative and regulatory framework for financial services as well as rural
       finance;

    -  creating adequate conditions conducive to the development of housing, commercial
       (industrial) and agroindustrial mortgage;

    -  introducing efficient mechanisms of refinancing the activities of mortgage creditors and
       mobilizing long-term resources to the financial sector.

       We look forward to our continued fruitful cooperation with the World Bank in supporting
the above mentioned program, aimed at improving access to finance for Ukrainian companies
and entrepreneurs in rural areas, developing stronger financial institutions and promoting modern
financial legal and regulatory framework. This support will help Ukraine to ensure sustainable
economic development, approximation to European Union, increased competitiveness of the
national economy as well as integration of Ukrainian financial system with international
financial markets.

                                                Sincerely,



                                            Victor Pynzenyk




                                                40

                                 Annex 4: Detailed Project Description
                UKRAINE: ACCESS TO FINANCIAL SERVICES PROJECT

1.   The Borrower and Implementing Agency for the project will be the Ministry of Finance.
The MoF will on-lend funds under Subcomponent A1 of Component A to eligible commercial
banks.

2.   The Project consists of the three main components, that are described in more detail below:

        ·   Component A: Access to finance, comprising: Subcomponent A1 - a line of credit for
            RSMEs, agricultural and micro enterprises, and SNGs; and Subcomponent A2 -
            institutional development for Participating Banks (PBs);
        ·   Component B: Enabling Environment for Financial Intermediation;
        ·   Component C: Project management, monitoring and audit.

Component A ­ Access to Finance

3.      This component includes two main subcomponents. The first would be a line of credit to
the selected Participating Banks (PBs), and the second would be institutional development
support for the PBs.

        A1      Line of Credit

        This comprises a Line of Credit of US$126 million to finance subloans through the three
        selected PBs for eligible micro-, agricultural and RSME sub-borrowers in rural areas
        (RSME) to finance their working capital and medium to longer term investments needs
        (including financial leasing contracts). As described below, subloans could also be made
        to SNGs. The PBs will assume all risks associated with on-lending to sub-borrowers.

        Eligible Participating Banks. Funds for this subcomponent will be on-lent by the MoF to
        the PBs (in US$ and UAH) under Subsidiary Loan Agreements, with terms and
        conditions that are satisfactory to the Bank. Three commercial banks (Pryvat, Nadra and
        Kreditprom) have been selected as PBs (see Attachment to this Annex for information on
        the PBs). Among the criteria used in their selection was the requirement that they must
        operate under sound commercial principles, meet minimum financial performance
        standards and be in full compliance with NBU prudential regulations. Detailed eligibility
        criteria for the PBs are provided in Annex 6 ­ Attachment 1.

        Eligible Sub-Borrowers. Eligible RSMEs will be private sector legal enterprises28 and
        entrepreneurs registered in Ukraine located in rural areas or individuals residing in rural
        areas of Ukraine. In addition, farmers and non-rural enterprises engaged in agricultural-
        related production will also be eligible. Lending to SNGs, on a pilot basis, could be
        considered for inclusion in the line of credit, if during project implementation satisfactory
        legislation on the SNG borrowing and guarantees is put in place and there is verifiable



28To be considered private, an enterprise must have more than 50% private ownership.


                                                       44

        demand from SNG eligible borrowers (municipalities and municipal enterprises).29
        Otherwise, SNG financing will be provided under Phase 2 of the Program. Eligible
        SNGs would need to demonstrate good financial management and capital planning
        practices. In the aggregate, maximum exposure by the PBs to any single borrower should
        not exceed US$4.0 million equivalent, or UAH 40 million in the case of SNGs.

        Eligible sub-projects include: (i) productive investments and financial leases in all sub-
        sectors of the rural economy (agriculture, services, and industry), and (ii) working capital
        loans for the same sub-sectors. The maximum size of a subloan (including for financial
        leases) for a productive investment would be $1.5 million equivalent. The maximum size
        of a working capital subloan would be $0.3 million equivalent. Sub-borrowers would be
        expected to provide 20 percent of the total sup-project cost from their own resources.
        Subloans below UAH 250,000 would be provided to small/microenterprises and
        entrepreneurs in rural areas to cover their investment or working capital needs. The
        maximum size of a subloan in the case of an SNG will be UAH 40 million. The
        requirements for sub-projects are provided in Annex 6, Attachment 1.

        A2: Institutional Development for PBs (Estimated cost about US$15 million)

        The project will finance consulting services and institutional development investments
        for eligible PBs to enhance their capacity and skills to lend to RSMEs and SNGs,
        consistent with the project objectives. This subcomponent could finance the costs
        associated with, inter alia: (a) developing and updating necessary technologies
        (computerized management information systems, risks management systems, new
        products and lending techniques, other soft and hardware) of banks that would ensure the
        provision of financial services to RSMEs and SNGs; (b) external training of banks' staff;
        and (c) consulting services for PBs to help develop new products and skills to enable
        them to reach new clients, especially rural and SNG borrowers.

        PBs may borrow the funds for these activities, in US dollars, from the MoF on the same
        terms and conditions as for Subcomponent A1, and will finance from their own funds at
        least 20 percent of the investment costs associated with IT expenditures. Activities under
        this subcomponent will be consistent with the PB's overall business strategy and planning
        and will be agreed with the Bank during the course of project implementation. Each PB
        may use up to 15 percent of the total amount of its Subsidiary Loan for its institutional
        development purposes. In addition, it is expected that, given the lead time needed, before
        for moving ahead with these activities, each PB will have disbursed at least 5 percent of
        its Subsidiary Loan for subloans to subborrowers. Staggering the use of funds for these
        investments will also serve to demonstrate the PB's interest in supporting the
        development objective of the project. Furthermore, if the PBs decide, during the course
        of project implementation, that they prefer to finance such activities from their own
        resources, they may shift these funds to Subcomponent A1.




29Such sub-projects would also be likely to support urgently required rehabilitation or equipment for vital services
while further attention is given to the application of appropriate cost recovery mechanisms and their management.


                                                           45

Component B: Enabling Environment for Financial Intermediation (Estimated cost US$8.0
million).

3.   This component supports institutional development to strengthen the legal, regulatory and
institutional framework for the financial sector. It will improve the enabling environment,
including infrastructure, for financial intermediation to RSMEs and SNGs. Substantial support
has already been provided through the PPF for this project to help develop primary legislation,
such as for subnational borrowing, mortgage finance and secured transactions. Further support
will be provided under the project, in close coordination with USAID and other donors, to focus
on implementation.

4.   Under this component, technical assistance through consulting services, IT/MIS
investments and training will be provided in the following areas:

        a. Subcomponent B1: Development of Non-bank Financial Services and Supervision.
           This includes support for the Non-bank Financial Institutions Regulator ­ the State
           Commission for Regulation of Financial Services Markets (SCRFSM) - to: (i)
           develop and establish the information/management systems needed for the SCRFSM
           to improve and effectively exercise its supervisory function strengthen its institutional
           capacity and develop modern supervisory techniques; (ii) improve procedures,
           regulations and legal framework for insurance, micro-credit, leasing and other NBFI
           services; (iii) develop new financial products and services, in such areas as
           agricultural risk insurance, warehouse receipts, leasing, etc.
        b. Subcomponent B2: Establishment of a Credit Bureau.            This includes technical
           assistance to support the development of a credit bureau to prepare, inter alia, the
           legal framework and internal procedures for the bureau's activities.
        c. Subcomponent B3: SNG Debt Market Development. This includes support for the
           Ministry of Finance to help create an adequate legal and regulatory framework for
           SNG borrowing; improve inter-budgetary relations and the debt management capacity
           of MoF and SNGs.
        d. Subcomponent B4: Development of the Mortgage Finance System. Support will be
           provided to help strengthen the recently created State Mortgage Institution (SMI) so
           that it can develop into an effective liquidity facility which refinances mortgage
           loans.   It will also provide support for the establishment of a sound legal and
           regulatory framework for housing finance.
        e. Subcomponent B5:        Other areas of institutional development support.           This
           subcomponent includes a provision for expertise that may become necessary during
           the project implementation but is not yet fully defined. This could include support for
           the Ministry of Finance in specific areas, including legal assistance, relating to
           eliminating constraints to access to financial services in rural areas, as well as for
           preparation of APL2.

Component C. Project Management and Monitoring (Estimated cost of US$1.6 million).

5.   The MoF has established a Project Management Unit (PMU) to manage the overall
implementation and coordination of project activities. This component will finance the staffing
costs of the PMU, as well as the incremental expenditures incurred by the MoF, through its


                                                46

PMU, in implementing the project and monitoring and evaluating its results. This includes, inter
alia: consultant services, telecommunications, furniture and office equipment and training. In
addition, it will support workshops and other activities to disseminate information about the
project and surveys to enhance project monitoring and evaluation. Financing the PMU from the
Loan for the AFSP has been agreed on an exceptional basis since the MoF does not have
adequate capacity to carry out this responsibility. It is envisaged that this is a transitional
arrangement as appropriate capacity will be developed through the management of this project so
that the PMU can be mainstreamed into the MoF by the time of APL2. This component will also
cover the cost of the annual audit of the Project accounts.




                                                 47

                                                                        Attachment to Annex 4

Pryvat Bank

1.      Pryvat Bank is the largest bank in Ukraine in terms of total assets, customer loans, total
deposits and shareholders' equity. In 2004 and 2005 the bank was also the market leader in
terms of net profit after tax. Pryvat Bank is a privately-owned universal bank offering a full
range of banking services to the corporate and SME markets as well as providing consumer
finance to individuals. As of October 1, 2005 the bank's total assets amounted to US$3,900
million and the bank had shareholders' funds of US$408 million. The head office of the bank is
located in Dnepropetrovsk, a major industrial city situated around 450 km. southeast of Kyiv.

2.      The bank has operated under a full banking license issued by the National Bank of
Ukraine (NBU) since March 1992. The bank currently has 42 major branches and regional
offices located throughout Ukraine's 25 administrative regions, with an especially high
concentration in the Dnepropetrovsk, Donetsk and Kyiv regions.          Considering all its sub-
branches, agencies and sub-agencies, the bank has more than 2,100 points of sale throughout
Ukraine. The bank is privately owned, with a small number of mostly local shareholders from
the Dnepropetrovsk region.

3.      Pryvat Bank caters particularly to manufacturing and industrial companies in the
Dnipropetrovsk and Donetsk regions of southeast Ukraine, but it also has a solid base in the Kyiv
region and elsewhere in the country. In recent years the bank has focussed more on SME and
retail lending to individuals. In corporate lending, the bank claims to have a market share of
around 10 percent, and in SME lending around 35 percent.


              Pryvat Bank Key Financial Data (US$ millions)

                                              End 2005       end-2004        end-2003
                                              (unaudited)     (audited)       (audited)
              Total Assets                          4,368        2,991       1,815
              Loan Portfolio                        3,187        1,775       1,425
              Deposits                              3,363        2,236       1,423
              Shareholders' Funds                     450          244        152
              Net Income after tax                     94           20          19

              Capital Adequacy Ratio (end of 2004): 11.5%



Nadra Bank

4.      Nadra Bank is the ninth largest bank in Ukraine in terms of assets. The bank had total
assets of US$733 million at the end of 2004 and over US$1.2 billion at the end of 2005. The
bank is a universal bank with a strong presence in the retail, SME and corporate sectors of the
market. It has been involved in a rapid expansion of its branch network in recent years and it
now has more than 500 branches throughout the country. It is a privately owned bank with a
relatively small number of significant shareholders.



                                                    48

5.      The bank has a focus on lending to large and medium sized enterprises, especially those
involved in production and import/export related activities.

2.        Kreditprom Bank

6.      Kreditprom Bank is one of the top twenty banks in Ukraine and in terms of capital and
was ranked number 14 in the banking system at end-2004. Kreditprom Bank is a universal bank
offering the full range of banking services to the corporate and SME markets as well as
providing consumer finance to individuals. In October 2005 the bank's total assets amounted to
US$446 million and the bank had shareholders' funds of US$64 million. By the end of 2005 its
assets increased to US$564 million. This bank was originally registered as Inkom Bank, but the
name was subsequently changed to Kreditprom Bank in September 1999. The bank is privately
owned with a small number of foreign and local shareholders.

7.      The bank currently has about 60 branches and 1,100 employees. The bank is expanding
its branch network to some other regions of the country and the management had a target to
reach 77 branches by end of the 2005. The bank increased its SME and consumer finance
operations significantly during 2004-2005. Kreditprom Bank has a particular strength in the
manufacturing and processing sectors and has built up a relationship with many of the larger
businesses in Ukraine.

8.      The profits of the bank increased from US$2 million in 2003 to US$2.8 million in 2004
and for the first half of 2005 a profit of US$1.8 million was recorded.
