                                                      50

                            Annex 6: Implementation Arrangements
               UKRAINE: ACCESS TO FINANCIAL SERVICES PROJECT


A.      Institutional and Implementation Arrangements

1.      The Ministry of Finance (MoF) will be the representative of the Borrower. It will also be
the implementing agency for the project and as such will have overall responsibility for ensuring
that the project is efficiently implemented and for the successful achievement of the project
objectives. The MoF has established a Project Management Unit (PMU) that has been managing
project preparation and will be responsible for the administration and monitoring of project
implementation activities. The Minister or Finance is the Project Coordinator and the primary
project counterpart. The Deputy Minister of Finance has been authorized to deal, on a daily
basis, with the Project's administrative and legalistic issues and is the primary counterpart for the
PMU on various non-strategic aspects of project implementation. Funds for Component A will
be on-lent to Participating Banks (PBs) as described below. MoF will administer and manage
the funds and activities for Components B and C.

B. On-lending Arrangements

2.      Funds for Component A will be on-lent by the MoF to the selected PBs under Subsidiary
Loan Agreements, satisfactory to the Bank. Conclusion of these agreements between the MoF
and at least two PBs will be a condition of effectiveness of the proposed project. The PBs will
be responsible for the implementation of this component. The PBs have been selected based on
criteria described in Attachment 1 to this Annex. These criteria, inter alia, are aimed to ensure
the PBs' capacity to carry out this task by requiring adequacy operational rules and procedures
and availability of human and financial resources. The criteria, as agreed with the Bank, will
also be the basis for ensuring the continued compliance of the PBs with the eligibility criteria
throughout project implementation.

3.      Component A. PBs will on-lend the funds under Subcomponent A1 of the project to the
eligible RSMEs and agricultural enterprises on market terms. The funds will be lent to the PBs
in US$ or Ukrainian hryvna (UAH) for on-lending in the same currency to the final beneficiaries.
On-lending to the RSMEs will be in UAH, except in cases where the final beneficiary is an
exporter. Eligibility criteria for final beneficiaries and subloans are provided in Attachment 1 to
this Annex.    The possibility of lending to SNGs on a pilot basis will be reviewed once
appropriate legislation, satisfactory to the Bank, has been passed relating to the authority of
SNGs to borrow and to the protection of creditors' rights. Funds for Subcomponent A2 will be
lent to the PBs in US$. The maximum amount of project funds allocated to each PB, based on
the negotiations of the MoF with the individual PBs, has been established as follows: (i)
Kreditprom Bank: US$43 million; (ii) Nadra Bank: US$46 million; and Pryvatbank: US$51
million.

4.      The interest rate charged by the MoF to the PBs for US$ funds will be equal to the 6-
month LIBOR plus 225 basis points. The interest rate charged to the PBs for the loans in UAH
will be equal to the NBU refinancing rate but not less than the 6-month LIBOR plus 425 basis



                                                  51

points, with the Ministry of Finance assuming the foreign exchange risk.30 This rate will be
adjusted semi-annually based on the movements of 6-month LIBOR. In addition, these spreads
will be reviewed from time to time during project implementation to adjust for changing cost
structure and risk considerations. The PBs will pay the MoF a commitment fee of 0.75 percent
on the amount pre-allocated to the PBs and a front-end fee of 1 percent on amounts withdrawn.
The subsidiary loans to the PBs will be for a maximum of 12 years, including a 2 year grace
period (on principal) (Attachment 1).

5.       All investment subloans of US$1.0 million equivalent or above require prior review and
approval by the PMU. The first two sub-projects above US$50,000 equivalent approved by each
participating bank, all investment sub-projects of US$1.0 million equivalent and above, and all
subloans to SNGS will be subject to prior review by the World Bank. Other subloans will be
subject to post-review by the Bank as part of project supervision. Guidelines to be followed by
the PMU in reviewing subloans will be incorporated in the Operations Manual (OM).31
Completion of the OM, satisfactory to the Bank and its approval by the MoF is a condition of
effectiveness of the Loan. Care will be taken to ensure that the PBs retain full responsibility for
approving subprojects as they will bear the credit risk.

6.       To help select PBs and monitor their continued compliance with project guidelines, the
MoF has established a Bank Selection and Monitoring Commission (BSMC). The BSMC is
chaired by the Minister of Finance; other members are the Deputy Minister of Finance, the
Deputy Governor of the NBU in charge of banking supervision, Director of the NBU
Department of Banking Supervision and the Director of the PMU. The PMU acts as its
Secretariat. The BSMC will be maintained throughout project implementation. The NBU will
play a key role assessment of continued eligibility of the PBs, and will confirm the PBs'
continued compliance with NBU prudential regulations. Continued compliance of each PB with
the eligibility criteria32 will be confirmed, quarterly, by the PB's management, as well as
annually by the external auditors.

C. Project Management Unit

7.       The PMU, headed by a Director, has been established under the MoF and has been
adequately staffed, including a Director, Procurement, Financial Management, Disbursement,
Legal and Banking Specialists as well as an Administrative Assistant.33 It will be responsible for
the overall administration of the project, coordination with project beneficiaries and reporting to
the Bank. The Project provides resources for additional consultants specialized in the areas of
subnational government finance, and non-bank financial services, financial sector policy reform,
procurement, financial management and monitoring and evaluation, as needed.

8.       Detailed implementation arrangements will be incorporated in the OM. The role of the
PMU is to facilitate project implementation. It will handle procurement of goods and services,
based on technical information provided by the beneficiary agencies. Beneficiary agencies will
retain responsibility for managing and overseeing contract execution and consultants'

30This spread over LIBOR includes a minimum foreign exchange risk spread of 200 basis points.
31These guidelines were confirmed during Negotiations.
32IAS-based ratios based on IAS definitions and methodologies
33Initial support for the PMU, including its staff, has been funded from the Project's PPF.


                                                          52

performance, to ensure that work is carried out in accordance with terms of reference that they
have provided. The PMU will monitor compliance with contractual or commercial terms of
contracts.

Monitoring and Evaluation.

9.       Progress in achieving the program's objectives will be measured through a
comprehensive monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system to be established by the PMU,
including the use of surveys of subloan beneficiaries. The M&E system will provide information
about specific quantitative targets for key indicators of project performance (see Annex 3), based
on data collected from the PBs and the beneficiaries of any project-related technical assistance.
A mid-term review to be held about, by about June 2008, will include a detailed assessment of
progress and achievements to date and will serve as the basis to determine readiness to proceed
with the APL2.

10.      The PBs and beneficiaries will maintain all records necessary to measure the
performance and viability of their project-related activities. Records will be available for review
by the PMU and Bank staff, as necessary. The PMU will prepare, and submit to the Bank for its
review, consolidated quarterly reports,34 based on information provided by the PBs and
beneficiaries. The Bank will conduct implementation reviews, as part of its normal supervision,
on a semi-annual basis, supplemented by more frequent reviews during the initial
implementation period. An Implementation Completion Report (ICR) will be prepared within
six months of the project's Closing Date.




34Formats for these reports were agreed with the Bank during Appraisal confirmed during Negotiations.


                                                       53

                                     Attachment 1 to Annex 6:
                          Selection Procedures for Participating Banks
                    Eligibility Criteria for Sub-Projects and Sub-Borrowers

Participating Banks

1.     The MoF, through the PMU, invited commercial banks to express their formal interest in
participating in the project.      This invitation detailed the eligibility criteria, including the
requirement that the banks had to be registered commercial banks in Ukraine and have been
profitable for at least two of the last three years. In addition the banks were required to authorize
the NBU and their external auditors to provide the World Bank access to information on any
specific issues that the Bank might need to be able to complete its appraisal of the banks and for
subsequent monitoring of their eligibility under the project. Detailed criteria include:

Statutory

·  Have a full banking license with NBU and have been in compliance with all the prudential
   and regulatory requirements of NBU for at least the last two consecutive years;
·  Have IAS/IFRS compliant financial reports for the past two years, audited by a reputable
   auditing firm that is acceptable to           Documentation to be provided by Commercial Banks seeking

                                                    54

·   Exposure to any single non-financial depositor (legal or natural person) should not exceed 30
    percent of total of liquid assets;
·   Total deposits of the 5 largest non-financial depositors (natural and legal persons) must not
    exceed 35 percent of assets with maturity of less than one month;
·   Total share of non-performing assets shall not exceed 8 percent of bank's assets;
·   Be fully compliant with loan loss provisioning requirements according to the NBU prudential
    regulations and IAS requirements;
·   NBU letter of comfort certifying that the participating banks are in full compliance with
    NBU regulatory and supervisory provisions;
·   Provide documentation relating to the management, staffing, operations, policies and
    procedures of the bank (see box 2)

2.       Each PB will have to maintain compliance with the above criteria throughout Project
implementation. MoF, through the PMU will monitor eligibility on a regular basis, based on
information provided by the NBU and the PBs. In addition, as part of their annual audits, the
banks will be required to provide, to the PMU and the World Bank, a letter from their external
auditors confirming compliance.            The Bank will review compliance as part of its regular
supervision activities.

Eligibility Criteria for RSMEs

Eligible RSMEs will be private enterprises and entrepreneurs registered in Ukraine located in
rural areas or enterprises engaged in agricultural-related production.35                     They will have to
demonstrate good financial management and capital planning practices. In addition, they should
have a debt service ratio of 1.5 and a debt equity ratio of 70/30. Beneficiaries would have to
provide at least 20 percent of the total investment cost of the subprojects. In the aggregate,
maximum exposure by the PBs to any single borrower should not exceed US$4.0 million
equivalent.

Eligible sub-projects would include:

· Investment loans or financial leases for RSMEs and agricultural enterprises, up to a maximum
  amount of US$1.5 million equivalent, for capital expenditures to expand, rehabilitate,
  modernize of existing production or service capacities. These subloans could finance up to 80
  percent of the total investment costs. On an exceptional and individual basis, the Bank could
  consider an increase in the maximum single sub-loan amount for agricultural enterprises.
· Working capital loans, up to a maximum amount of US$300,000 equivalent, to cover
  operating needs.
· Small/micro loans up to a maximum amount of UAH 250,000 (about US$50,000 equivalent)
  to cover investment or working capital needs of entrepreneurs and individuals operating or
  residing in rural areas.




35Entrepreneurs and enterprises with less than 20 employees with the ability to service and repay sub-loans can
qualify for micro/small sub-loans below US$50,000 equivalent.



                                                       55

Subloan Terms and Conditions

The maturity of investment sub-projects will have a maximum of 10 years, including a grace
period for the repayment of principal of up to 12 months. Working capital loans will have a
maturity of up to 3 years. The maximum maturity (repayment term) for a small/micro loan is 7
years.

Subloans will be made on commercial terms at market rates, in accordance with subloan
agreements to be concluded between the PBs and their customers (the final beneficiary). The PB
will bear all commercial risks associated with the subloans and the PMU will have only a review
function to ensure compliance with the Project requirements.




                                                56

              Annex 7: Financial Management and Disbursement Arrangements
                UKRAINE: ACCESS TO FINANCIAL SERVICES PROJECT

1. Country Financial Management Issues

Previous Bank diagnostic and Economic and Sector Work (ESW) concluded that significant
improvement is required in public expenditure management, especially strengthening internal
and external audits in the public sector. The CFAA also identified a lack of adequate
accountability arrangements for state owned enterprises. While there has been some progress
since the publication of Bank reports in terms of bringing modern technology into the public
finance management area, major institutional reforms, such as restructuring fragmented and
overlapping functions, pose a major challenge. The next phase of reforms is expected to focus on
deepening existing reforms and widening the scope of the reform agenda. This will entail
significant changes in and realignment of institutional structures.

The 2002 Report on Observance of Standards and Codes (ROSC) on Accounting and Auditing
identified weak regulatory arrangements for the audit profession, differences between National
Accounting Standards and IFRS, and weak capacity in the country to implement IFRS financial
statements and ISA audits.

In order to address some of the weaknesses, the reports recommended enhanced controls in
Projects. Such arrangements usually include ex-ante and ex-post controlling procedures. Internal
controls for the project are described below and documented in the Operations Manual.

2. Introduction

The Project will be implemented through a PMU in the MoF.                 The MoF will be the
representative of the Borrower and have overall responsibility for project implementation.

The task team conducted an assessment of the adequacy of the project financial management
systems at the PMU during project appraisal. The financial management arrangements for the
project are satisfactory to the Bank.

3. Summary

A detailed financial management questionnaire is included in the project files. A summary of the
conclusions are as follows:

            Financial Management Assessment                              PMU
            1. Implementing Entity                                       Satisfactory
            2. Funds Flow                                                Satisfactory
            3. Staffing                                                  Satisfactory
            4. Accounting Policies and Procedures                        Satisfactory
            5. Internal Audit                                            Satisfactory
            6. External Audit                                            Satisfactory
            7. Reporting and Monitoring                                  Satisfactory
            8. Information Systems                                       Satisfactory
                        OVERALL FINANC1AL MANAGEMENT RATING              Satisfactory



                                                  57

4. Risk Analysis

A summary of the risk assessment for the project identified the following risks:
Inherent Risk                           Comments
Country Financial Management Moderate   Based on CFAA report dated 2001, and update of assessment performed
Risk: weaknesses in the public          in 2004.
sector financial management
Project Financial Management   Moderate The current project design has not been used in any previous Ukrainian
Issues                                  Bank-financed projects.
Banking sector                 Moderate The banking sector is subject to NBU regulations and supervision.
                                        Selected PBs are fully compliant with NBU prudential regulations and
                                        requirements, and will be required to maintain compliance throughout
                                        implementation. Although the banking sector has strengthened
                                        significantly and improved quality of its services, it remains relatively
                                        inefficient. It remains susceptible to external and macroeconomic
                                        shocks. Some of these risks can be mitigated by ongoing efforts to
                                        strengthen NBU's supervisory capacity.
Overall inherent risk         MODERATE
Control Risk                   PMU      Comments
1. Implementing Entity         Moderate The PMU has been established in the MoF for the Project. Most of staff
                                        within the PMU has gained some experience in handling the fiduciary
                                        aspects of the Project through implementation of the PPF for the Project.
2. Funds Flow                  Moderate Funds flow arrangements are acceptable. Funds flow will be through: (i)
                                        a Special Account opened by MoF to accounts of the PBs or final
                                        contractors; or (ii) directly from the loan account to the accounts of the
                                        PBs or final contractors. PMU will coordinate all documentation flows.
3. Staffing                    Low      Staffing of the PMU established for the Project is adequate. Qualified
                                        staff will act according to the job specifications as set out in the
                                        Operations Manual. All PMU staff will be project-funded on annual
                                        renewable contracts.
4. Accounting Policies and     Moderate PMU accounting policies and procedures, satisfactory to the Bank (i) are
Procedures                              in compliance with Ukrainian regulations and (ii) accommodate needs.
                                        Project, as is detailed in the draft Operations Manual.
5. Internal Audit              High     The Project activities will be subject to internal audit checks of the MoF.
                                        However, as these audits are transaction-based, rather than control-based,
                                        the Bank will not rely on the internal audit function of MoF.
6. External Audit              Low      An independent auditor acceptable to the Bank will audit the Project
                                        financial statements, in accordance with ToR acceptable to the Bank.
7. Reporting and Monitoring    Low      PMU has the capacity for Project reporting and monitoring. The FMRs
                                        will be provided to the Bank quarterly. Project reporting will be subject
                                        to regular Bank supervision.
8. Information Systems         Moderate PMU has implemented information systems, which are adequate to
                                        process and maintain Project-related data and produce required reports.
9. Control Risks at PBs        Low      No additional staff need to be hired at PBs. Existing accountants will
                                        handle the additional accounting and reporting functions for the Project
                                        using regular PBs' accounting policies and procedures. Each of the
                                        selected PB has an internal audit function which will regularly review the
                                        policies and procedures for granting loans and project accounting, in
                                        accordance with NBU regulations and conditions of the Bank as
                                        stipulated in the Loan agreement, Subsidiary Loan Agreement, and
                                        Operations Manual. The PBs' financial statements prepared under
                                        requirements of IFRS will be audited at least annually. The FS of the PBs
                                        have been audited for at least each of the past 2 years.
Overall Control Risk          MODERATE



                                                  58

5.      Risk Mitigation Strategy

Although, the country financial management risk is moderate, the PMU has gained some
experience from implementation of the PPF for the Project. Training on financial management
and procurement will be provided by the Bank to the PMU and the PBs, as necessary.

The project financial management arrangements have been designed to mitigate the inherent risk
through a combination of intense Bank supervision, selection of PBs with strong accounting and
reporting systems, requiring audits of the PBs and Project financial statements, and monitoring
of periodic reports as described in the corresponding sections below.

6.      Strengths and Weaknesses

Strengths:

- Prior experience of PMU on working with the Bank during implementation of the PPF for the
  AFSP. Qualified staff have the required technical skills and are fluent in English.

- Strong PBs have been selected with unqualified audit reports for the past two years. The PBs
  have some prior experience of working with other international organizations. The PBs will
  also have strong financial management systems.

- A procedure will be implemented for prior review by the Bank of first two sub-loans of each
  PB and of each sub-loan in excess of US$1 million. In addition, the maximum sub-loan
  amount will be US$1.5 million.

- Training workshop for FM and Procurement specialists at PMU and PBs will be held by the
  Bank.

Weaknesses:

  - The Project involves a number of components and on-lending to PBs: as a result, FMRs will
  require close monitoring by the Bank.

  - the PMU has not been involved in previous Bank-funded projects.

  - No reliable internal audit at the PMU level.

7.      Implementing Entity

The MoF is the main counterpart for the Project. Funds for Component A would be on-lent by
the MoF to qualified PBs under Subsidiary Loan Agreements, satisfactory to the Bank. For
Subcomponent A1, the PBs would make subloans to the final beneficiaries (RSMEs, agricultural
enterprises and SNGs). Subcomponent A2 will be on-lent by the MoF to the PBs for their
institutional/IT development needs. MoF, through the PMU, will administer and manage the
funds and activities for Components B and C.


                                                59

PMU: The PMU, headed by a Director, has been established and adequately staffed. The PMU
is responsible for the overall administration of the project, coordination with the beneficiary
agencies and reporting to the Bank and the MoF. The PMU will be responsible for all fiduciary
functions: management of flow of funds, preparation of financial reports and audits.

PBs: PBs will have the key role in implementing Component A of the project. Subloans to final
beneficiaries will be made on commercial terms, in accordance with the policies and procedures
of the PBs. PBs will bear the commercial risk and will be responsible for subproject appraisal
and all lending decisions. Subloans to RSMEs could be made in US$ (for exporters) or UAH.

8.      Funds Flow and Disbursement Arrangements

For the purposes of the Project, the MoF through the PMU will open and manage a Special
Account (SA) in a Ukrainian commercial bank acceptable to the World Bank. Measures, such as
appropriate protection against set-off, seizure and attachment, in the case of a commercial bank
will have to be taken. The allocation to the SA for the Project will not exceed US$15 million.

The funds flow scheme assumes that project funds will flow from the Bank via the single Special
Account which will be replenished on the basis of SOEs, or by direct payment on the basis of
withdrawal applications. The Special Account will have two analytical sub-accounts for the
purpose of separate accounting for Component A and for Components B and C (these two
groups of Project Components are two lines in the State Budget). Co-financing provided by PBs
for Subcomponent A2 will not require any special accounts.

For Component A, the PBs will receive loan funds according to the Subsidiary Loan
Agreements. These funds, at request of PMU, will be provided to the PBs through the Special
Account or by direct transfer of funds to the accounts of PBs against documented disbursements
for eligible subloans. For the purpose of receiving the Project funds, the PBs will not be required
to have a project account: they will only set up a separate account in their accounting systems to
record the receipt and transfer of the loan funds by the PBs.

The PMU will submit a replenishment application monthly, or sooner if desired, but quarterly at
the latest. A bank statement and reconciliation of the SA against the World Bank's records will
support the replenishment applications. The minimum amount for application for direct payment
and for special commitment is 20 percent of the authorized allocation to the SA.

Funds from the Bank Loan will be disbursed under transaction-based procedures including SOEs
and direct payments. Supporting documentation for SOEs, including completion reports and
certificates, will be retained by the Borrower and made available to the Bank during project
supervision. The Loan will finance 100 percent of the amounts disbursed against subloans. All
disbursements will be made on the basis of full documentation for (a) contracts for goods costing
more than the equivalent of US$500,000 each; (b) contracts for works costing more than the
equivalent of US$5,000,000 each; and (c) services under contracts of more than the equivalent of
US$200,000 for each consulting firm and more than the equivalent of US$100,000 each for
individual consultants. Disbursements below these thresholds, as well as for training, study tours,
for PMU operating costs, sub-loan agreements, and micro projects will be made according to the


                                                 60

Statement of Expenditure (SOEs). This documentation will be made available for the required
audit as well as for Bank supervision missions, and will be retained for at least one year after
receipt by the Bank of the audit report for the year in which the last disbursement was made.
Disbursements for expenditures above the SOE thresholds will be made against presentation of
full documentation relating to those expenditures.

9.      Staffing

PMU staff includes a financial management (FM) specialist. All PMU staff will be selected in
accordance with Bank procurement guidelines for the appointment of individual consultants and
will have the minimum required qualifications as described in the Operations Manual. The
detailed job specifications are included in the Operations Manual. All PMU staff will be
employed on annual renewable contracts, subject to adequate performance.

Fiduciary functions of operating the Project will be performed by the financial management
specialist, who has worked with the Bank on implementation of PPF for the Project. These
functions include preparation or review of all documentation relating to requests of
disbursements and subsidiary loans, and all accounting and reporting functions. The FM
specialist will be supervised by the head of PMU, and report to the World Bank on all financial
management issues.

Existing employees of the PBs will perform the accounting and reporting for all transactions for
sub-borrowing and sub-lending within the Project. A qualified current employee of each PB will
be nominated for the preparation of Bank-specific documentation and reporting.

10.     Accounting Policies and Procedures

Accounting and reporting policies and procedures of the PMU are described in the draft
Operations Manual. In addition to the accounting and reporting to the Bank, PMU will also
maintain adequate accounting records to provide reports to the Treasury/MoF. The draft
Operations Manual prescribes detailed procedures including internal controls and internal
reporting to enable the PMU maintain appropriate accounting and reporting, acceptable to the
Bank.

In accordance with the accounting and reporting policies and procedures to be applied for the
project:
    ·    Reports will be submitted to the Bank on a quarterly basis, and include all disclosure
        information required by the Bank.
    ·   All counterpart funds (if any) and co-financing of PBs will be reflected in the financial
        statements.

The director of PMU and the FMS will be responsible for ensuring that the prescribed
accounting policies and procedures are followed. This will also be monitored by the Bank during
at least annual supervisions.




                                               61

The internal controls procedures include internal authorizations, regular reconciliations of
accounts internally and with banks, segregations of duties within PMU, in-built software
controls, post-review, and are documented in detail in Operations Manual.

The first two sub-loans of each PB, all sub-loans to RSMEs of US$1.0 million equivalent and
above, and all subloans to SNGs would be subject to prior review by the Bank. The PMU would
review all such applications and provide their own recommendations on whether they meet the
eligibility criteria, prior to submission to the Bank. All other sub-loans would be subject to post-
review by the Bank. The maximum size of sub-loans for RSMEs and agricultural enterprises
would be US$1.5 million equivalent, unless the Bank, on an exceptional basis, agrees otherwise.

11.     Internal Audit

No reliance will be placed on the internal audit function of the MoF for the purpose of this
project, as the internal audit department of MoF uses transaction-based rather than control-based
approach to internal audit procedures.

12.     Reporting and Monitoring

Quarterly financial reports would be provided to the Bank on the basis of current PMU financial
reports and FMRs, which will include: (a) Financial Reports (sources and uses of funds by
components; Special Account statement) (b) Project Progress Reports; and (c) Procurement
Management Reports.

PMU will prepare these reports based on its own accounting information, and information
received from the PBs and other project beneficiaries. The PBs and other project beneficiaries
will forward their quarterly reports to the PMU for review and consolidation.

13.     Information Systems

The PMU has a standard off-the-shelf accounting software, modified for the purpose of
maintaining the accounting and reporting function. The internal system of the MoF will not be
used for the purpose of Project accounting and reporting. Reporting to meet Treasury/MoF
requirements will be done using the internal system of accounting and reporting of
Treasury/MoF.

The PBs will use their own accounting and reporting system. The PBs accounting systems are
able to maintain all accounting data on the project-related activities and produce required
reporting.

14.     Supervision Plan

During project implementation, the Bank will supervise the Project's financial management
arrangements in the following main ways:

    (i)     Review of the quarterly financial reports



                                                  62

    (ii)    Review of annual audited Project financial statements and audited PBs financial
            statements along with management letter
    (iii)   During the Bank's annual supervision missions:
            ·   Review of the project's financial management and disbursement arrangements
            ·   Review of a sample of SOEs and movements on the Special Accounts to ensure
                compliance with the Bank's minimum requirements.

15.      Audit

The Project financial statements prepared will be audited under ISA by an acceptable auditor.
These financial statements will include information on counterpart financing. A management
letter will be provided along with the financial statements.

The PMU will also collect and forward to the Bank annual audited financial statements of the
PBs along with the management letter, as specified in the Subsidiary Loan Agreements, within
six months after end of each fiscal year. The banks' financial statements will be prepared under
requirements of IFRS and will be audited under ISA by an acceptable auditor in accordance with
the acceptable ToR. Each PB will also provide letters, issued by the PB's auditor as well as by its
own management, certifying that it is in compliance with the eligibility criteria specified in the
Subsidiary Loan Agreements. The letter of certification will be included in TOR for audit of the
PBs financial statements. The certification may be included in the full set of IFRS financial
statements of each PB.

All annual audited project financial statements will be provided to the Bank within six months
after the end of each fiscal year. Each contract for the audit of the Project accounts will be
awarded during the first year of Project implementation and thereafter extended annually with
the same auditor, subject to satisfactory performance of the appointed auditor. The cost of the
Project audit may be financed from the proceeds of the Loan.

16.     Action plan

       Required action                                             Responsible Due date

  1. Finalize the Operations Manual                                PMU             Before effectiveness

     and Incremental Operating Costs

                                                     63

                                      Annex 8: Procurement
                UKRAINE: ACCESS TO FINANCIAL SERVICES PROJECT

A. General

Procurement for the proposed project will be carried out in accordance with the World Bank's
"Guidelines: Procurement Under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits" dated May, 2004; and
"Guidelines: Selection and Employment of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers" dated May
2004, and the provisions stipulated in the Legal Agreement. The various items under different
expenditure categories are described in general below. For each contract to be financed by the
Loan/Credit, the different procurement methods or consultant selection methods, the need for
pre-qualification, estimated costs, prior review requirements, and time frame are agreed between
the Borrower and the Bank in the Procurement Plan. The Procurement Plan will be updated at
least annually or as required to reflect the actual project implementation needs and improvements
in institutional capacity.

A General Procurement Notice (GPN) will be published in the May 2006 issue of the
Development Business and in dgMarkets announcing goods and consulting services to be
procured and inviting interested eligible suppliers and consultants to express interest and to
request any complementary information from the Borrower. Specific Procurement Notices
(SPN) will be published in the on-line edition of the Development Business for all ICB contracts,
and in the printed edition at the option of the Borrower. For goods to be procured through ICB,
individual bidding opportunities will also be advertised in a major local newspaper on the same
(or within 5) day(s) of the on-line publication. The local advertisements will be in the English
language and, at the option of the Borrower, will also be in the local language. For consultants'
contracts above US$200,000, SPN/Request for Expression of Interest will be advertised in on-
line edition of the Development Business and in at least one major national newspaper of wide
circulation (in the national and English languages). No advertising will be mandatory in respect
of any Contract procured using commercial practices. Civil servants can be hired as individual
consultants or as members of a team with financing under the Loan provided they are on leave of
absence without pay and they have not been working for any of the Beneficiary Agencies
immediately prior to taking leave of absence.

Procurement of Works: Works procured under this Project may include minor investments
under Subcomponent A1 (Line of Credit). It is envisaged that for all contracts estimated to cost
less than US$2 million procurement will be done under Commercial Practices. However, for all
contracts estimated to cost in excess of US$2 million, the procurement will be done using the
Bank's Standard Bidding Documents (SBD) for all ICB and agreed documents where works are
procured under NCB. It is envisaged that all works where estimated value per contract is less
than US$5 million but more than US$2 million may be procured using NCB procedures. In
cases where Works are related to the construction of new buildings the Bank would require that
the beneficiary should have a clear title to the land prior to commencing the investment. It is not
envisaged that there will be any works contracts under any of the other components. For any
refurbishments and preparation works which are relatively small (less than $100,000 equivalent
per site) a shopping procedure (see below) may be used using the Minor Works SBDs.




                                                  64

Procurement of Goods: Goods procured under this project will be procured under all
Components. Under Subcomponent A1 (Credit Line) goods estimated to cost less than US$2
million per contract may be procured in accordance with established commercial practices.
However, any recipients that fall under the requirements of the Ukraine Law on Public
Procurement must use the appropriate procurement methods and procedures included in the Law
for contracts up to that amount, and for contracts above this threshold to follow the procedures
outlined below. Under Subcomponents A2 and Component B, goods financed by the Loan will
include the procurement of several large contracts for information technology (IT) equipment
and software and some small contracts for IT, software and ancillary equipment. Major IT
equipment contracts will include the delivery of incidental services including installation,
commissioning and training of recipients in their use and maintenance. For all goods estimated
to cost above US$2 million per contract under Component A and all goods procured under the
remaining Components, in so far as possible procurement will be done using the Bank's SBD for
all ICB (in the case of IT equipment the specific information systems documents for single and
two stage Bidding will be used) and National SBD agreed with or satisfactory to the Bank.
However, for the supply of specific specialized equipment, where there is a limited number of
suppliers, an LIB procedure may be used. This is recommended and justified by the fact that
there are only a limited number of firms who can provide this equipment.

In so far as possible goods will be packaged in the most economic way possible to reduce the
number of individual procurement procedures and considering project objectives, and into
package sizes that would encourage competitive bidding. The following methods would be used:

    (i)    International Competitive Bidding (ICB). Goods under subcomponent A2 and
           components B and C of the Project for contracts above US$500,000 equivalent per
           contract will be procured using ICB procedures in accordance with the Bank's
           Procurement Guidelines. In the evaluation of bids for goods procured through ICB,
           domestic preference would apply in accordance with the provisions of the
           Procurement Guidelines. The latest Bank Standard Bidding Document (SBD) for the
           Procurement of Goods, or Procurement of Information Technology will be used, as
           appropriate, using single or two stage bidding depending on the complexity of the
           procurement.

    (ii)   Limited International Bidding (LIB). For goods where there are a limited number of
           manufacturers or suppliers who are known to the Borrower Limited International
           Bidding may be used. This procedure will be implemented in accordance with
           paragraph 3.2 of the Procurement Guidelines. A detailed list of items and names of
           all potential suppliers, as well as bidding documents, will be submitted to the Bank
           for prior review and approval.

    (iii)  Shopping (SH) procedure will be used for readily available off-the-shelf goods,
           including office and computer equipment for the Beneficiary Agencies and for minor
           computer equipment for the PCU. All items, estimated to cost less US$100,000
           equivalent per contract, would have standard specifications. This procedure will be
           based on obtaining and comparing price offers from at least three suppliers from at
           least two different countries in accordance with paragraph 3.5 of Procurement
           Guidelines. It is recommended that the World Bank shopping site be used to draw up


                                                65

            shortlists for simple computer equipment. The ECA Regional sample format for
            shopping "Invitation to Quote" should be used. In the case of Works Shopping
            procedures will be used for contracts estimated to cost less than US$100,000
            equivalent.

    (iv)    National Competitive Bidding (NCB). Under subcomponent A1 and components B
            and C, goods estimated to cost less than $500,000 equivalent per contract, and Works
            estimated to cost less than $5,000,000 under Subcomponent A1, may be procured
            according to NCB procedures in accordance with paragraphs 3.3 and 3.4 of the
            Bank's Procurement Guidelines using documents agreed with and acceptable to the
            Bank and taking into account the exceptions indicated in the Loan Agreement.

    (v)     Direct Contracting. Where certain goods are of a proprietary nature and are available
            only from a particular supplier or in cases where compatibility with existing
            equipment so requires goods may be procured under Direct Contracting (Single
            Source) having obtained prior approval from the Bank (in accordance with para. 3.6
            of the Procurement Guidelines).

Procurement of non-consulting services: At this stage it is not foreseen to procure any non-
consulting services.

The various Sub-projects under Subcomponent A1 will be financed jointly by the project's
credit line through PBs and by final beneficiaries' own funds.              The above procurement
thresholds will apply to the total contract value for a sub-project, regardless of the percentage of
Bank financing provided.

In no case will the goods and works under subcomponent A1 of Component A be procured by
sub-borrowers and PBs from a source or a business entity in which that sub-borrower or PB has a
financial or business interest.

Selection of Consultants: Contracts for Consulting Services will be packaged to combine
related skills and services in order to make them attractive for competition and reduce the
number of contracts to be administered, taking into consideration the size and capacity of the
PMU. To the extent practicable, training activities will be incorporated with consulting services
contracts. Consultant services consist of short-and long-term assignments to be contracted with
firms and/or individuals (national and/or foreign or jointly) depending on the nature and duration
of the assignments. Selection procedures will be managed through competition among qualified
short listed consultants. The short lists for consultant services contracts with firms shall comprise
six firms with a wide geographical spread, and with no more than two firms from any one
eligible country. The procurement of consultant services contracts financed under the Loan will
be in accordance with the provisions of the Consultant Guidelines. For consulting assignments
exceeding US$200,000 equivalent per contract, expressions of interest will be obtained by
advertisement in the Development Business (on-line), supplemented with notices issued in the
national press.

Under Subcomponent A1 of component A, contracts for consultancy, technical assistance or
training, estimated to cost up to US$200,000, may be procured in accordance with established


                                                  66

commercial practices. Recipients that fall under the requirements of the Ukraine Law on Public
Procurement must use the appropriate procurement methods and procedures included in the Law
for contracts up to that amount, and for contracts above this threshold to follow the normal Bank
procedures outlined in this section.

Short lists of consultant firms for services estimated to cost less than US$100,000 equivalent per
contract may be composed entirely of national consultants in accordance with the provisions of
paragraph 2.7 of the Consultant Guidelines.

The following procurement procedures will be used for selection of consultant services:

    (i) Quality and Cost Based Selection (QCBS) procedures, as described in Section II, paras
         2.1 to 2.31 of the Consultant Guidelines will be used for assignments under all
         Components of the Project;

    (ii) Least Cost Selection (LCS) procedure will be used for selection of an auditor to carry
         out audit of the Financial Statements of the Project.

    (iii) Selection Based on Consultants' Qualifications (CQ) will be used for contracting firms
         for certain assignments under all components of the project for which the value of the
         assignments is estimated to cost less than US$200,000 equivalent per contract and
         where it is considered that a small team of specialists would be more beneficial than a
         single individual.

    (iv) Individual Consultants (IC). Many specialized activities where specific skills are
         needed for short periods of time at scattered intervals and which would not be practical
         to package with the assignments for consulting firms described above, will be best
         served through the recruitment of individual consultants (both foreign and national). In
         some cases there may also be a need for a long term individual adviser. Selection of
         individual consultants will be carried out in accordance with Section V of the
         Consultant Guidelines. Individuals will be selected on the basis of their qualifications
         for the assignment by comparing the CVs obtained in response to an advertisement in
         the national press or Development Business. PMU staff will be selected as individual
         consultants;

    (v) Sole Source (SS). The method will be used for certain individuals with prior approval
         of the Bank in accordance with paras. 3.9 to 3.13 of the Consultants Guidelines.

Training Activities: Training is an integral element of the project's capacity building objective.
The Loan will finance training programs, including training workshops, study tours and local
training. Such training programs will be included in larger TA contracts with firms to reduce
administrative burden on the PMU. The PMU will be responsible for administration of a small
number of local workshops (including project launch, mid term and completion workshops) and
a number of study tours for the Beneficiary Agencies and PMU specialists. Expenses for study
tours and off-the-shelf training related to the project would be covered under training category.
The Bank will periodically review and clear the list of proposed study tour candidates, the nature
of the study tour(s)/training, the place and period of the study tour(s), estimated costs, etc.


                                                 67

Expenditures related to such training activities include: (a) for local training and workshops ­ per
diems of participants to cover transportation, lodging and subsistence; minor organizational
expenses (stationery, handouts, training materials, coffee breaks); (b) for international study
tours ­ international travel and visa costs, per diems (lodging and subsistence) and course-related
expenses (fixed tuition or participation fee). Design of the training courses and study tours may
be carried out by the specialists contracted as short term consultants under relevant QCBS, CQ
and/or IC procedures depending on the value of the assignment as described above in this Annex.

The PMU is expected to prepare and agree a training plan with the Bank every year. Estimated
budget, list of participants and draft agenda for each training event will be subject to Banks prior
review. Expenditure items for training activities, including study tours, will be reported under
SOEs. The status of the training plan will be included as part of the quarterly progress reports,
and will be updated and/or modified as may be mutually agreed between the coordination units
and the Bank.

Operating Costs: Incremental operating costs incurred by the PMU for communications and
office supplies will be financed under the Credit for the duration of the project. In addition,
recurrent costs related to operating and maintenance of equipment provided under the project for
the PMU and generated by the project, including the day-to-day operational costs for office
equipment and maintenance, consumables, will be financed by the government.

Others: No Special Arrangements

The procurement procedures and SBDs to be used for each procurement method, as well as
model contracts for works and goods procured, are presented in the Project Operations Manual.

B. Assessment of the agency's capacity to implement procurement

Country Issues
A Country Procurement Assessment Review (CPAR) for the Ukraine was finalized in 2001 and
indicates a "high" risk based on the assessment of the country's national procurement system.
This CPAR has recently been updated, unfortunately this assessment has revealed a significant
deterioration in the public procurement framework (both the legislative and institutional). The
changes made to the PPL in 2004 and 2005 make the current Law largely at variance with
international standards and as such, together with the current institutional framework make it
unacceptable for use in the context of "certification for use of country systems" under World
Bank financed projects.      This is due to shortcoming concerning the following fundamental
issues:
a)     lack of clarity in respect of the current institutional structure of procurement;
b)     lack of standard bidding documents and standard contract forms;
c)     lack of recognition of consultancy services in the PPL;
d)     lack of clear written procedures for tendering, evaluation and contracting;
e)     overuse of restrictions, exemptions and exceptions from PPL thus restricting competition;
f)     unrestricted use of a merit points system leading to ineffective, un-transparent and costly
procurement;



                                                  68

g)      apparent coercive practices forcing procuring entities to make expenditures which are not
in the public interest;

There is also a concern regarding the ability of the local marketplace to provide a robust
competitive bidding environment at the current NCB thresholds, if during implementation it is
shown that only one or two Bidders are in a position to participate in the Bidding process, the
Borrower may ultimately face higher costs from lack of competition. Therefore the Bank will
need to address the issue of marketplace capacity as evidenced in the results of Bidding in the
first year of the project. Evidence of a limited market may indicate a need to scale back and
lower thresholds, thus allowing greater opportunity for international competition where local
markets are sparse.

A short review of Commercial Practices in Ukraine was undertaken during pre-appraisal in
October 2005 of the proposed Export Development Project (which is being processed in parallel
with this operation). The review revealed that significant changes and improvements had
occurred in recent years as companies came to understand that they could look beyond their
traditional suppliers. The most common practice now being followed is market research using
such tools as the internet, attendance at conferences, professional exhibitions etc., followed by
more direct approaches to companies identified as being potential suppliers. In most cases,
Invitations to Quote are sent to the top 3 or 4 identified companies, and selection is based on the
optimal combination of price and other factors (quality, delivery, etc.). There is, however, a
remaining concern about the ability of the local marketplace to provide a robust competitive
bidding environment. This will be closely monitored by the Bank during the Ex-Post review
process of commercial practices.

An assessment of the capacity of the Implementing Agency to implement procurement actions
for the project was carried out by the Procurement Accredited Specialist (PAS) assigned to the
project during appraisal in February 2006. The assessment reviewed the organizational structure
for implementing the project and the interaction between the project's staff responsible for
procurement and the Ministry's relevant central unit for administration and finance. Overall
responsibility for procurement management will rest with the PMU. The PMU is staffed with a
Director, a procurement specialist and procurement assistant, in addition to other staff.

The key issues and risks concerning procurement for implementation of the project have been
identified and include lack of experience in implementing all the required procurement methods.
In particular procurement of IT technologies has been identified as an area where the PMU may
need strengthening. The corrective measures which have been agreed include the hiring of short-
term experienced Consultants. In addition the following Action Plan to strengthen the conduct
of procurement and the capacity at the Implementing Agency is recommended:

-    procurement staff of the Ministry of Finance, as the implementing agency, should be given
     the opportunity to attend intensive public procurement training in either English or Russian
     language, offered by ILO Turin;
-    briefings and training will be provided for senior management and the members of the
     Tender Committee in Bank procurement procedures.
-    technical assistance for the large IT procurement packages will be obtained.



                                                 69

-    consulting services for assistance in preparation of design and supervision tender
     documentation will be provided;
-    the project will be subject to intense supervision by the Bank with close monitoring of
     activities;
-    initiating a Project Launch Workshop before effectiveness, as part of the project
     implementation/capacity building initiatives, especially in procurement.         This will be
     supplemented by further training for procurement staff and members of Evaluation
     Committees;
-    conduct of annual joint reviews of the Procurement Plan and review of contracts that will be
     subject to prior review.
-
The overall project risk for procurement is High.

C. Procurement Plan

The Procurement Plan contains all the relevant procurement information, including prior review
thresholds for Bank financed contracts. For procurement under the Loan, with the exception of
items procured under commercial practices the Borrower will use the Bank's latest Standard
Bidding Documents (SBD), Standard Form of Consulting Contracts and Request for Proposals
(RFP), and Standard Bid Evaluation Report Forms. For NCB procedures acceptable Bidding
Documents will be agreed. The Standard Bidding Documents for procurement of Information
Systems will be used for procurements of all IT equipment estimated to cost over US$100,000
per contract. These will comprise Supply and Installation of Information Systems - Single Stage
Bidding or Supply, and Installation of Information Systems - Two Stage Bidding (both version
March 2003 or more recent). Also, the sample procurement documents and forms developed in
ECA Region for small value procurement will be adapted to suit the Project needs for
procurement as outlined in the Operations Manual.

It is not possible to estimate who the sub-borrowers may be, nor their procurement requirements
for Subcomponent A1 of Component A of the Project. Therefore, it is not possible for the
Borrower to develop a Procurement Plan which provides the basis for the procurement methods
for individual contracts for this Component. For Subcomponent A2 and Components B and C,
the Borrower has developed a Procurement Plan for project implementation which provides the
basis for the procurement methods. This plan was agreed between the Borrower and the Bank on
May 22, 2006 and is available at the offices of the PMU. It will also be available in the project's
database and in the Bank's external website. The Procurement Plan will be updated in agreement
with the Bank annually or as required to reflect the actual project implementation needs and
improvements in institutional capacity. Procurement of goods, works and services for the project
will be carried out in accordance with the agreed procurement plan.

D. Frequency of Procurement Supervision

In addition to the prior review supervision to be carried out from Bank offices, the capacity
assessment of the Implementing Agency has recommended two supervision missions per year to
visit the field to carry out post review of procurement actions. It is envisaged that 2 out of every
5 procurements will be reviewed ex-post.



                                                 70

E. Details of the Procurement Arrangements Involving International Competition

1. Goods, Works, and Non Consulting Services
(a) List of contract packages to be procured following ICB, NCB and direct contracting:
    See Procurement Plan (below)

(b) ICB contracts estimated to cost above $500,000 equivalent per contract (for Goods), NCB
    contracts estimated to cost above $300,000 equivalent per contract (for Goods), and all direct
    contracting will be subject to prior review by the Bank. All ICB and the first two NCB
    contracts will also be subject to prior review. All ICB contracts for Works, all NCB
    estimated to cost above $3,000,000 equivalent per contract and the first two NCB contracts
    shall also be subject to Prior Review.

2. Consulting Services
(a) List of consulting assignments with short-list of international firms:
    See Procurement Plan (below)

(b) Consultancy services estimated to cost above $200,000 equivalent per contract for firms and
    $100,000 equivalent per contract for individuals and single source selection of consultants
    will be subject to prior review by the Bank. The first CQ contract and first two IC contract
    irrespective of price will also be subject to Prior Review

(c) Short lists composed entirely of national consultants: Short lists of consultants for services
    estimated to cost less than $100,000 equivalent per contract may be composed entirely of
    national consultants in accordance with the provisions of paragraph 2.7 of the Consultant
    Guidelines.




                                                  71

                                 PROCUREMENT PLAN

I. General
1.    Agreed Date of the procurement Plan
      Original    : May 22, 2006
      Revision 1 :....................

      Date of General Procurement Notice: estimated May 2006

II. Goods and Works and non consulting services

1.    Prior Review Threshold: Procurement Decisions subject to Prior Review by Bank as
      stated in Appendix 1 to the Guidelines for Procurement :

      Procurement Method         Prior Review                        Comments
                                  Threshold
 1.   ICB and LIB (Goods)     > $500,000         All subject to Prior Review
 2.   NCB (Goods)             > $300,000         First 2 and all subject to prior review
 3.   Shopping (Goods)        < $100,000         None
 4.   Direct Contracting*     -                  All subject to Prior Review
 5.   ICB (Works)             > $5,000,000       All subject to Prior review
 6.   NCB (Works)             > $3,000,000       First 2 and all subject to prior review
 7.   Shopping (Works)        < $100,000         First works contract subject to prior review
 8.   Minor Works             < $100,000         First works contract subject to prior review
 9.   Commercial Practices    Any                First for each PFI
       * all Contracts subject to justification

2.    Pre-qualification. Bidders shall be pre-qualified in accordance with the provisions of
      paragraphs 2.9 and 2.10 of the Guidelines (No pre-qualification is envisaged)
3.    CDD Procurement Manual: Project components to be carried out by community
      participation in accordance with the provisions of paragraph 3.17: No CDD is envisaged
4.    Any Other Special Procurement Arrangements: Commercial Practice.                     Contracts
      resulting from on lending to financial intermediaries, initially estimated to cost less than
      US$2 million, to be reviewed may be procured using established private sector
      (commercial) practices, which are acceptable to the Bank.              In the event that the
      Beneficiary funds are usually subject to the Law on Public Procurement the procurement
      shall be in accordance with the provisions of the said Law.
5.    Procurement Items with Methods and Time Schedule: See below




                                               72

III. Selection of Consultants

    1. Prior Review Threshold: Selection Decisions subject to Prior Review by Bank as stated
       in Appendix 1 to the Guidelines Selection and Employment of Consultants:

             Selection Method               Prior Review                 Comments
                                             Threshold
 1.    Competitive Methods (Firms)      > $200,000            All subject to prior review
       QCBS
 2.    Competitive Methods (Firms)      Any amount            First contract subject to prior
       LCS                                                    review
 3.    Competitive Methods (Firms)      < $200,000            First contract subject to prior
       CQ                                                     review
 4.    Individual Consultants (IC)      > $100,000            First 2 contracts and all subject to
                                                              prior review
 5.    Single Source (Firms and         -                     All subject to prior review
       Individuals)*
 6.    ToRs for Consulting Contracts    All methods/values    All subject to prior review
 7.    Commercial Practices             Any                   First for each PB
* all Contracts subject to justification

    2. Short list comprising entirely of national consultants: Short list of consultants for
       services, estimated to cost less than $100,000 equivalent per contract, may comprise
       entirely of national consultants in accordance with the provisions of paragraph 2.7 of the
       Consultant Guidelines.

    3. Any Other Special Selection Arrangements: Commercial Practice. Contracts resulting
       from on lending to financial intermediaries, initially estimated to cost less than
       US$200,000, to be reviewed may be procured using established private sector
       (commercial) practices, which are acceptable to the Bank.             In the event that the
       Beneficiary funds are usually subject to the Law on Public Procurement the procurement
       shall be in accordance with the provisions of the said Law;

    4. Consultancy Assignments with Selection Methods and Time Schedule: See below

IV. Other
    1. Ex-Post Review: All other contracts below Bank's prior review threshold are subject to
       Bank's selective ex-post review.        Periodic ex-post review by Bank staff will be
       undertaken during regular supervision missions. Procurement documents, such as bidding
       documents, bids, bid evaluation reports and correspondence related to bids and contracts
       will be kept readily available for Bank's ex-post review during supervision missions or at
       any other points in time. Bank missions will review at least 2 out of every 5 contracts
       which are subject to ex-post review.

Record Keeping: The PMU will maintain complete procurement files which will be reviewed
by Bank supervision missions. All procurement related documentation that requires Bank prior
review will be cleared by Procurement Accredited Staff (PAS) and relevant technical staff. No
packages above mandatory review thresholds by RPA are anticipated. Procurement information


                                                 73

will be recorded by the PMU and submitted to Bank as part of the quarterly (FMRs) and annual
progress reports. A simple management information system with a procurement module would
be established to assist the PMU procurement specialists to monitor all procurement information.

                           Annex 9: Economic and Financial Analysis
               UKRAINE: ACCESS TO FINANCIAL SERVICES PROJECT



Not applicable. It is impossible to estimate the financial and economic rates of return for the line
of credit as the specific sub-projects are not pre-selected. The lending guidelines for PBs would,
however, require that the repayment capacity (based on investment cash flows) of the sub-
borrower is clearly established. Technical assistance, institutional development, and project
management and monitoring activities do not lend themselves to cost benefit analysis.




                                                 77

                                    Annex 10: Safeguard Policy Issues

                  UKRAINE: ACCESS TO FINANCIAL SERVICES PROJECT

Background

The AFSP provides loans to rural small and medium enterprises, including entrepreneurs, and
agricultural enterprises, as defined in Ukrainian law. Lending to subnational governments on a
pilot basis may also be possible when the appropriate framework (including legislation),
satisfactory to the Bank is in place.

All sub-projects to be financed under the AFSP will be subject to an environmental review
process utilizing the procedures described in Guidelines on Environmental Assessment
Requirements, Identification of Impacts and Mitigation, contained in the OM.36 These Guidelines
are intended to provide those responsible for assessing the viability of sub-projects simple step
by step guidelines/procedures to ensure that sub-projects receive the required attention from an
environmental point of view. The PBs, with assistance, as appropriate, of the PMU in the MoF,
will be required to follow these procedures as part of the overall appraisal of sub-borrowers/sub-
projects. The procedures are consistent with both the environmental policies and regulations of
the Government of Ukraine and the World Bank (OP/BP/GP 4.01 Environmental Assessment
and OP 4.09 Pest Management).

Sub-project Screening

All sub-projects proposed for financing from Bank funds through PBs will be screened and
classified into one of the three Categories (A, B, or C). Given the focus of this project and scope
of the sub-projects, it is expected that the vast majority of sub-projects will fall into Category C.
The Screening Procedure is described in the above-mentioned Guidelines.

Pest Management

Since declaring its independence in 1991, Ukraine has established its own system of
environmental laws. Environmental review and impact assessment of existing and proposed
activities in Ukraine are governed by its state ecological expertiza procedure. The 1991 Law on
Environmental Protection established the framework for this procedure. The legislation provides
for the execution of state ecological expertizas and EIA37 documentation for both planned and
existing activities that impact the environment.38 Although the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine,
government of Crimea, local Radas, local executive bodies, institutions of the Ministry of
Health, and other state executive bodies participate in Ukraine's state ecological expertiza
system,39 primary responsibility for the organization and execution of these expertizas currently
rests with the Ministry of Environmental Protection (MEP), its local agencies, and their


36 These Guidelines are based on the Environmental Review conducted in October 2002 for the Rural Finance
Project (which was subsequently revised and transformed into the AFSP).
37Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) is the same as an Environmental Assessment (EA) and reflects differences
in terminology used by the authorities and the World Bank.
38 Law of Ukraine on Environmental Protection, Articles 26-30, 51. All references to Ukrainian law are to English
translations of the law and may not reflect the exact meaning of the Ukrainian legislation.
39Law of Ukraine on Ecological Expertiza, Article 20.
                                                         78

subdivisions. In certain cases, other institutions, experts, organizations, and individuals are
permitted to participate.

The ecological expertiza is just one of many kinds of expertiza conducted to assess the
compliance of economic activities with Ukrainian laws and regulations. In addition to state
ecological expertizas, the law also authorizes public organizations, independent specialists, and
local governments to conduct public ecological expertizas on their own initiative. If drafted, the
conclusions of public expertizas serve as recommendations to the agency conducting the state
ecological expertiza and to those submitting the proposal. Further, Article 9 of the Law on
Environmental Protection confers the right on the citizens of Ukraine to take part in discussions
about, and to submit comments on, draft legislation and materials relating to siting, construction,
or modification of objects that might negatively affect the environment.

The role of environmental impact assessment is further defined by the 1995 Law on Ecological
Expertiza, which declares that state ecological expertizas are mandatory for "activities and
facilities posing an increased ecological hazard," as defined by the Cabinet of Ministers of
Ukraine in a List of Activities and Objects Which Constitute an Increased Ecological Hazard.
This list was compiled and approved soon after the Law on Ecological Expertiza was enacted.
For these activities and objects, the law directs the ecological expertiza to define the degree of
environmental risk and safety of a planned or current "object" of ecological expertiza; to conduct
comprehensive scientifically-based assessments of the objects and their impacts on
environmental conditions and public health; to ensure compliance of expertiza objects with
environmental, public health and building standards and regulations; to evaluate the sufficiency
of environmental and public health measures; and to prepare unbiased, well-founded
conclusions. The conclusions are based in large part on "documentation" submitted to the
ecological expertiza by the proponent of an activity or project on its environmental and other
impacts ("EIA documentation").

The Ukrainian system of laws and regulations regarding production, transportation, use and other
types of handling pesticides and agrochemicals includes the Law of Ukraine on Pesticides and
Agrochemicals (1995) and resolutions of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine on various issues
related to testing and registration, inventory, licensing of handling and phase-out, disposal or
destruction of these substances. In accordance with this legislation, application of methyl
bromide alternatives will take place only after necessary testing and registration of chemicals has
occurred and operators have necessary licenses for handling pesticides and agrochemicals, issued
by Ministry of Environmental Protection. Key principles of the state policy regarding handling of
pesticides and agrochemicals ensure: (a) priority of human and environmental health, (b) state
control over imports, (c) registration of all types of handling (production, storage, transportation,
sale and application), (c) justification of applications and minimization of use through
application of environmentally-friendly methods (non-chemical methods of plant protection).

Agricultural sub-projects under AFSP, which involve application of pesticides and agricultural
chemicals, would trigger the Bank's safeguard policy on pest management. It is expected that
sub-projects involving pesticides and other agricultural chemicals will be small scale. However,
to minimize risks to human health and environment and mitigate potential negative
consequences, the pest management plan (PMP) for such sub-projects was developed during
project preparation and is included in the above-referenced Guidelines.
